performance.head: Society.
performance.p: First performed at the Prince of Wales Theatre, Liverpool, (under the management of Mr. A. Henderson,) on the 8th of May, 1865, and at the Prince of Wales's Theatre, London, (under the management of Miss Marie Wilton,) on the 11th of November, 1865.

body.head: Society.

div.stage: Scene first. —Sidney Daryl's Chambers, in Lincoln's Inn; set door piece R. and set door piece L. (to double up and draw off) ; the room to present the appearance of belonging to a sporting literary barrister; books, pictures, whips, the mirror stuck full of cards (painted on cloth) ; a table on R., chairs, &c.
As the curtain rises a knock heard, and Doddles discovered opening door, L.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: (without) Mr. Daryl in ?

sp.speaker: Dodd.
sp.p: Not up yet.
sp.stage: Enter Tom Stylus, Chodd, Jun., and Chodd, Sen.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: (L., looking at watch) Ten minutes to twelve, eh, guv?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: (R. C.) Late into bed; up after he oughter; out for brandy and sobering water.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: (within) Doddles.

sp.speaker: Dodd.
sp.p: (R., an old clerk) Yes, sir!

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Brandy and soda.

sp.speaker: Dodd.
sp.p: Yes, sir!

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: I said so! Tell Mr. Daryl two gentlemen wish to see him on particular business.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: (a supercilious, bad swell—glass in eye, hooked stick—vulgar and uneasy) So this is an author's crib—is it ?—don't think much of it, eh, guv ? (crossing behind to L. C.)

sp.speaker: Chodd, Sen.
sp.p: (a common old man, with a dialect) Seems comfortable enough to me, Johnny.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: Don't call me Johnny ?—I hope he won't be long! (looking at watch) Don't seem to me the right sort of thing; for two gentlemen to be kept waiting for a man they are going to employ.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Sen.
sp.p: Gently, Johnny. (Chodd, Jun., looks annoyed) I mean gently without the Johnny.—Mister

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Daryl—Sidney Daryl!

sp.speaker: Chodd, Sen.
sp.p: Daryl didn't know as we was coming!

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: (rudely to Tom) Why didn't you let him know ?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: (fiercely) How the devil could I?—I didn't see you till last night. (Chodd, Jun., retires into himself) You'll find Sidney Daryl just the man for you ; young— full of talent—what I was thirty years ago;—I'm old now, and not full of talent, if ever I was; I've emptied myself;—I've missed my tip. You see I wasn't a swell —he is!

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: A swell—what a man who writes for his living?
sp.stage: Doddles enters, door, r.

sp.speaker: Dodd.
sp.p: Mr. Daryl will be with you directly; will you please to sit down ?

div.stage: (Chodd,Sen., sits L. C. , Tom takes a chair L., of table; Chodd, Jun., waits to have one given to him, is annoyed that no one does so, and sits on table—Doddles goes round to L.)

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: Where is Mr. Daryl ?

sp.speaker: Dodd.
sp.p: In his bath!

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: (jumping off table) What! you don't mean to say he keeps us here while he's washing himself?
sp.stage: Enter Sidney Daryl in morning jacket, door R.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Sorry to have detained you; how are you, Tom?

p.stage: (Tom and Chodd Sen., rise, Chodd, Jun., sits again on table and sucks cane.)

sp.speaker: Chodd, Sen.
sp.p: Not at all!

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: (with watch) Fifteen minutes.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: (crossing, c, handing chair to Chodd, Jun.) Take a chair!

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: This'll do.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: But you're sitting on the steel pens.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Dangerous things! pens.
sp.stage: (Chodd, Jun., takes a chair L.)

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Yes ! loaded with ink, percussion powder's nothing to 'em.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: We came here to talk business, (to Doddles) Here, you get out!

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: (surprised) Doddles—I expect a lot of people this morning, be kind enough to take them into the library.

sp.speaker: Dodd.
sp.p: (L.) Yes, sir! (aside looking at Chodd, Jun.) Young rhinoceros ! Exit door, L.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Now, gentlemen, I am—(crossing behind table to R.)

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: (L. of table) Then I'll begin,—first let me introduce Mr. Sidney Daryl, to Mr. John Chodd of Snoggerston, also to Mr. John Chodd, Jun., of the same place; Mr. John Chodd of Snoggerston is very rich;—he made a fortune by —

sp.speaker: Chodd, Sen.
sp.p: No !—my brother Joe made the fortune in Australey, by gold digging and then spec'lating; which he then died, and left all to me.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: (aside) Guv ! cut it!

sp.speaker: Chodd, Sen.
sp.p: I shant,—I ain't ashamed of what I was, nor what I am ;—it never was my way. Well, sir, I have lots of brass !

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Brass?

sp.speaker: Chodd, Sen.
sp.p: Money?

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: Heaps!

sp.speaker: Chodd, Sen.
sp.p: (L. C. ) Heaps; but having begun by being a poor man, without edication, and not being a gentleman :

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: (aside) Guv!—cut it.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Sen.
sp.p: I shan't—I know I'm not, and I'm proud of it, that is proud of knowing I'm not, and I won't pretend to be. Johnny, don't put me out—I say I'm not a gentleman, but my son is.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: (looking at him) Evidently.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Sen.
sp.p: And I wish him to cut a figure in the world—to get into Parliament.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Very difficult.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Sen.
sp.p: To get a wife ?

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Very easy.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Sen.
sp.p: And in short, to be a—a real gentleman.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Very difficult.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: Eh?

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: I mean very easy.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Sen.
sp.p: Now, as I'm anxious he should be an M.P. as soon as —

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: As he can.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Sen.
sp.p: Just so, and as I have lots of capital unemployed, I mean to invest it in —

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: (slapping Sidney on knees) A new daily paper ?

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: By Jove!

sp.speaker: Chodd, Sen.
sp.p: A cheap daily paper, that could—that will— What will a cheap daily paper do ?

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Bring the "Court Circular" within the knowledge of the humblest.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Educate the masses—raise them morally, socially, politically, scientifically, geologically, and horizontally.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Sen.
sp.p: (delighted) That's it—that's it, only it looks better in print.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: (spouting) Bring the glad and solemn tidings of the day to the labourer at his plough—the spinner at his wheel—the swart forger at his furnace—the sailor, on the giddy mast—the lighthouse keeper, as he trims his beacon lamp—the housewife, at her paste-board—the mother at her needle—the lowly lucifer seller, as he plashes his wet and weary way through the damp, steaming, stony streets, eh ?—you know, (slapping Sidney Daryl on the knee—they both laugh)

sp.speaker: Chodd, Sen.
sp.p: (to Chodd, Jun.) What are they a laughing at?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: So my old friend, Johnny Prothero, who lives hard by Mr. Chodd, knowing that I have started lots of papers, sent the two Mr. Chodds, or the Messrs. Chodd— which is it ? you're a great grammarian—to me. I can find them an efficient staff, and you are the first man we've called upon.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Thanks, old fellow. When do you propose to start it ?

sp.speaker: Chodd, Sen.
sp.p: At once.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: What is it to be called?

sp.speaker: Chodd, Sen.
sp.p: We don't know.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: We leave that to the fellows we pay for their time and trouble.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: You want something

sp.speaker: Chodd, Sen.
sp.p: Strong.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: And sensational.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: I have it. (rising)

sp.speaker: Tom| Chodd, Senr.|Chodd, Jun
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: (rising) The "Morning Earthquake! "

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: (rising) Capital!

sp.speaker: Chodd, Sen.
sp.p: (rising) First rate!

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: (still seated) Not so bad. (goes up during next speech)

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Don't you see? In place of the clocki.e. the clock on the masthead of The Times., a mass of houses—factories, and palaces tumbling one over the other; and then the prospectus ! "At a time when thrones are tottering, dynasties dissolving—while the old world is displacing to make room for the new"

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Bravo!

sp.speaker: Chodd, Sen.
sp.p: (enthusiastically) Hurray!

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: A second edition at 4 o'clock, p.m. The "Evening Earthquake, eh ? Placard the walls. "The Earthquake," one note of admiration; "The Earthquake," two notes of admiration; "The Earthquake," three notes of admiration. Posters : "'The Earthquake' delivered every morning with your hot rolls." " With coffee, toast, and eggs, enjoy your 'Earthquake!'"

sp.speaker: Chodd, Sen.
sp.p: (with pocket book) I've got your name and address.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: (who has been looking at cards stuck in glass, C.) Guv. (takes old Chodd up and whispers to him)

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: (to Sidney) Don't like this young man !

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Cub.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Cad.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Never mind. The old un's not a bad 'un. We're off to a printer's.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Good bye, Tom, and thank ye.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: How's the little girl ?

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Quite well. I expect her here this morning.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Sen.
sp.p: Good morning.
Exeunt Chodd, Sen., and Tom, door, L.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: (filling pipe, &c.) Have a pipe?

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: (taking out a magnificent case) I always smoke cigars.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Gracious creature! Have some bitter beer ?

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: I never drink anything in the morning.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Oh!

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: But champagne.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: I haven't got any.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: (L.) Then I'll take beer, (they sit) Business is business—so I'd best begin at once. The present age is as you are aware—a practical age. I come to the point—it's my way. Capital commands the world. The capitalist commands capital, therefore the capitalist commands the world.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: (R.) But you don't quite command the world, do you ?

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: Practically, I do. I wish for the highest honours—I bring out my cheque book. I want to get into the House of Commons—cheque book. I want the best legal opinion in the House of Lords—cheque book. The best house—cheque book. The best turn out—cheque book. The best friends, the best wife, the best trained children—cheque book, cheque book, and cheque book.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: You mean to say with money you can purchase anything ?

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: Exactly. This life is a matter of bargain.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: But "honour, love, obedience, troops of friends."Macbeth V.iii

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: Can buy 'em all, sir, in lots as at an auction.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Love, too?

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: Marriage means a union mutually advantageous. It is a civil contract like a partnership.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: And the old-fashioned virtues of honour and chivalry ?

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: Honour means not being a bankrupt, I know nothing at all about chivalry, and I don't want to.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Well, yours is quite a new creed to me, and I confess I don't like it.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: The currency, sir, converts the most hardened sceptic. I see by the cards on your glass that you go out a good deal.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Go out?

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: Yes, to parties, (looking at cards on table) There's my Lady this, and the Countess t'other, and Mrs. somebody else. Now that's what I want to do.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Go into society ?

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: Just so. You had money once, hadn't you?

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: What did you do with it ?

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Spent it.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: And you've been in the army ?

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: Infantry?

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Cavalry.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: Dragoons?

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Lancers.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: How did you get out of it ?

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Sold out.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: Then you were a first-rate fellow, till you tumbled down?

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Tumbled down!

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: Yes, to what you are.
sp.stage: (Sidney about to speak, is interrupted by Moses Aaron, without, L.)

sp.speaker: Moses.
sp.p: Tell you I mush't shee him.
sp.stage: Enter Moses Aaron with Doddles, door L.

sp.speaker: Moses.
sp.p: (not seeing Chodd, going round behind table) Sorry, Mister Daryl, but at the shoot of Brackersby and Co. (arrests him)

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: Je-hosophat! (rising)

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Confound Mr. Brackersby! It hasn't been owing fifteen months !—How much?

sp.speaker: Moses.
sp.p: With exes, fifty-four pun' two.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: I've got it in the next room. Have some beer.

sp.speaker: Moses.
sp.p: Thank ye, shir. (Sidney pours it out)

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Back directly. Exit, door, L.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: (L.) This chap's in debt. Here you!

sp.speaker: Moses.
sp.p: (R.) Shir.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: Mr. Daryl—does he owe much ?

sp.speaker: Moses.
sp.p: Spheck he does, shir, or I shouldn't know him.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: Here's half-a-sov. Give me your address ?

sp.speaker: Moses.
sp.p: (gives card) "Orders executed with punctuality and dispatch."

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: If I don't get into society now, I'm a Dutchman.
sp.stage: Enter Sidney, R.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Here you are—ten fives—two two's—and a half-a-crown for yourself.

sp.speaker: Moses.
sp.p: Thank ye, shir. Good mornin', shir.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Good morning.

sp.speaker: Moses.
sp.p: (to Chodd) Good mornin', shir.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: Such familiarity from the lower orders.
sp.stage: Exit Moses Aaron, door, L.
sp.p: You take it coolly, (sitting L. of table)

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: (sitting) I generally do.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: (looking round) You've got lots of guns?

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: I'm fond of shooting.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: And rods ?

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: I'm fond of fishing.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: And books ?

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: I like reading.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: And whips ?

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: And riding.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: Why you seem fond of everything?

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: (looking at him) No ; not everything.
sp.stage: Doddles enters, at door, L., with card.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: (reading) "Mr. Sam. Stunner, P.R."

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: "P.R." What's P.R. mean? Afternoon's P.M.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Ask him in. Exit Doddles.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: Is he an author? or does P.R. mean Pre-Raphaelite ?

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: No ; he's a prize-fighter—the Smiffel Lamb.
sp.stage: Enter the Smiffel Lamb, L. door.
sp.p: How are you, Lamb ?

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.p: Bleating, sir, bleating—thankee kindly.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: (aside to Sidney) Do prize fighters usually carry cards ?

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: The march of intellect. Education of the masses—the Jemmy MasseysJem or Jemmy Massey (1831-1910): bare-knuckle prize fighter; owner of Kings Head in Old Compton Street "a noted haunt for patrons of the sport of ratting" . Have a glass of sherry ?

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.p: Not a drain, thankee, sir.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: (aside) Offers that brute sherry, and makes me drink beer.

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.p: I've jist bin drinkin' with Lankey Joe, and the Dulwich Duffer, at Sam Shoulderblows. I'm a going into trainin' next week to fight Australian Harry, the Boundin' Kangaroo. I shall lick him, sir. I know I shall.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: I shall back you, Lamb.

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.p: Thankee, Mr. Daryl. I knew you would. I always does my best for my backers, and to keep up the honour of the science; the Fancy, sir, should keep square, (looks at Chodd, hesitates, then walks to door, closes it and walks sharply up to Sidney Daryl—Chodd leaping up in alarm, and retiring to back—leaning on table and speaking close to Sidney Daryl's ear) I jist called in to give you the office, sir, as has always bin so kind to me, not to put any tin on the mill between the Choking Chummy and Slang's Novice. It's a cross, sir, a reg'lar barney!

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Is it ? thank ye.

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.p: That's wot I called for, sir; and now I'm hoff. (goes to door—turning) Don't putt a mag on it, sir: Choking Chummy's a cove, as would sell his own mother; he once sold me, which is wuss. Good day, sir.Exit Lamb, door, L.
sp.stage: Chodd reseats himself.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: As I was saying, you know lots of people at clubs, and in society.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: Titles, and Honorables, and Captains, and that.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: Tiptoppers. (after a pause) You're not well off ?

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: (getting serious) No.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: I am. I've heaps of brass. Now I have what you haven't, and I haven't what you have. You've got what I want, and I've got what you want. That's logic, isn't it ?

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: (gravely) What of it?

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: This: suppose we exchange or barter. You help me to get into the company of men with titles, and women with titles ; swells, you know, real uns, and all that.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: And I'll write you a cheque for any reasonable sum you like to name.
sp.stage: Sidney rises indignantly, at the same moment little Maud and Mrs. Churton enter door, L.

sp.speaker: L. Maud.
sp.p: (running to Sidney) Here I am, uncle; Mrs. Churton says I've been such a good girl.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: (kissing her) My darling. How d'ye do, Mr. Churton. I've got a waggon, and a baa lamb that squeaks, for you. (to Little Maud—then to Chodd, Jun.) Mr. Chodd, I cannot entertain your very commercial proposition. My friends, are my friends; they are not marketable commodities. I regret that I can be of no assistance to you. With your appearance, manners, and cheque book, you are sure to make a circle of your own.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: You refuse, then

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Absolutely. Good morning.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: Good morning, (aside) And if I don't have my knife into you, my name's not John Chodd, Jun.

div.stage: Exeunt Sidney, Little Maud and Mrs. Churton, door, R.—Chodd, door, L.

Scene Second.—The Interior of a Square at the West-end. Weeping ash over a rustic chair, C, trees, shrubs, walks, rails, gates, &c.;—houses at back—time evening—effect of setting sun in windows of houses—lights in some of the windows, &c,—street lamps.
Maud discovered in rustic chair reading; street band heard playing in the distance.

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p:
I can't see to read any more. Heigho! how
lonely it is! and that band makes me so melancholy:— sometimes music makes me feel—(rising) Heigho! I suppose I shall see nobody to-night; I must go home. (starts) Oh ! (Sidney appears at L. gate,) I think I can see to read a few more lines, (sits again, and takes book)

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: (feeling pockets) Confound it ! I've left the key at home, (tries gate) How shall I get in! (looking over rails) I'll try the other, (goes round at back to opposite gate)

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: Why, he's going ! He doesn't know I'm here. (rises, calling) Sid—No I won't, the idea of his—(sees Sidney at gate, R.) Ah! (gives a sigh of relief, reseats herself and reads)

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: (at gate, R.) Shut too! (trying gate) provoking! what shall I—(sees Nursemaid approaching with Child from L. 1 E.,—drops his hat into square) Will you kindly open this? I've forgotten my key. (Girl opens gate) Thanks ! (he enters square; Girl and Child go out at gate ;—Life Guardsman enters, R. U. E., speaks to Girl, they exeunt, L. U. E.—Sidney sighs on seeing Maud) There she is ! (seats himself by Maud) Maud!

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: (L., starting) Oh! is that you? who would have thought of seeing you here!

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: (r.) Oh, come—don't I know that you walk here after dinner? and all day long I've been wishing it was half-past eight.

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: (coquetting) I wonder, now, how often you've said that, this last week.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Don't pretend to doubt me, that's unworthy of you. (a pause) Maud !

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Are you not going to speak ?

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: (dreamily) I don't know what to say.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p:
That's just my case. When I'm away from you, I feel I could talk to you for hours; and when I'm with you, somehow or other, it seems all to go away. (getting closer to her, and taking her hand) It is such happiness to be with you, that it makes me forget everything else, (takes off his gloves and puts them on seat) Ever since I was that high, in the jolly old days down at
Springmead, my greatest pleasure has been to be near you. (looks at watch) Twenty to nine. When must you return ?

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: At nine.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Twenty minutes. How's your aunt ?

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: As cross as ever.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: And Lord Ptarmigant?

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: As usual—asleep.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Dear old man! how he does doze his time away, (another pause) Anything else to tell me ?

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: We had such a stupid dinner; such odd people.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Who?

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: Two men of the name of Chodd.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: (uneasily) Chodd!

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: Isn't it a funny name ?—Chodd.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Yes, it's a Chodd name—I mean an odd name. Where were they picked up ?

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: I don't know. Aunty says they are both very rich.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: (uneasily) She thinks of nothing but money. (looks at watch) Fifteen to nine, (stage has grown gradually dark) Maud ?

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: (in a whisper) Yes.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: If I were rich—if you were rich—if we were rich?

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: Sidney! (drawing closer to him)

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: As it is, I almost feel it's a crime to love you.

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: Oh, Sidney!

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: You who might make such a splendid marriage.

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: If you had—money—I couldn't care for you any more than I do now.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: My darling! (looks at watch) Ten minutes. I know you wouldn't. Sometimes I feel mad about you— mad when I know you are out and smiling upon others— and—and waltzing.

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: I can't help waltzing when I'm asked.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: No, dear, no; but when I fancy you are spinning round with another's arm about your waist. (his arm round her waist) Oh!—I feel

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: Why, Sidney, (smiling) You are jealous?

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Yes, I am.

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: Can't you trust me ?

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Implicitly. But I like to be with you all the same.

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: (whispering) So do I with you.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: My love! (kisses her, and looks at watch) Five minutes.

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: Time to go?

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: No ! (Maud, in taking out her handkerchief, takes out a knot of ribbon) What's that ?

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: Some trimmings I'm making for our fancy fair.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: What colour is it. Scarlet ?

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: Magenta.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Give it to me ?

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: What nonsense.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Won't you ?

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: I've brought something else.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: For me?

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: These, (producing small case, which Sidney opens)

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Sleeve links!

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: Now, which will you have, the links or the ribbon ?

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: (after reflection) Both.

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: You avaricious creature !

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: (putting the ribbons near his heart) It's not in the power of words to tell you how I love you. Do you care for me enough to trust your future with me? Will you be mine ?

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: Sidney!

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Mine, and none other's; no matter how brilliant the offer—how dazzling the position.

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: (in a whisper—leaning towards him) Yours and yours only ! (clock strikes nine)

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: (with watch) Nine ! Why doesn't time stop, and big Ben refuse to toll the hour? (Lady and Lord Ptarmigant appear and open gate, R.)

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p:
(frightened) My aunt! (Sidney gets to back,
round L. of square—Lord and Lady Ptarmigant advance)

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: ( a very grand acid old lady) Maud!

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: Aunty, I was just coming away.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: No one in the Square ? Quite improper to be here alone, Ferdinand!

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: (a little old gentleman) My love?

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: What is the time ?

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: Don't know—watch stopped—tired of going I suppose, like me.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: (sitting on chair—throws down the gloves left by Sidney with her dress) What's that? (picking them up) Gloves?
Maud, (frightened) Mine, aunty!

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Yours? You've got yours on! (looking at them) These are Sidney Daryl's. I know his size— seven-and-a-half. I see why you are so fond of walking in the square; for shame! (turning to Sidney, who has just got the R. gate open, and is going out) Sidney! (fiercely) I see you ! There is no occasion to try and sneak away. Come here. (Sidney advances. With ironical politeness) You have left your gloves, (all are standing except Lord Ptarmigant, who lies at full length on chair and goes to sleep)

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: (confused) Thank you, Lady Ptarm ——

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: You two fools have been making love. I've long suspected it. I'm shocked with both of you; a penniless scribbler, and a dependant orphan, without a shilling or an expectation. Do you (to Sidney) wish to drag my niece, born and bred a lady, to a back parlour, and bread and cheese? Or do you (to Maud) wish to marry a shabby writer, who can neither feed himself or you ? I can leave you nothing, for I am as well bred a pauper as yourselves, (to Maud) To keep appointments in a public square ! your conduct is disgraceful—worse— it is unladylike ; and yours (to Sidney), is dishonorable, and unworthy, to fill the head of a foolish girl, with sentiment and rubbish, (loudly) Ferdinand.

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: (waking up) Yes, dear.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Do keep awake; the Chodds will be here directly; they are to walk home with us, and I request you to make yourself agreeable to them.

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: Such canaille.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Such cash!

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: Such cads.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Such cash! Pray Ferdinand, don't argue. (authoritatively)

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: I never do. (goes to sleep again)

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: I wish for no esclandre. Let us have no discussion in the square. Mr. Daryl, I shall be sorry if you compel me to forbid you my house. I have other views for Miss Hetherington. (Sidney bows)
The two Chodds in evening dress appear at gate, R..—- they enter.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: My dear Mr. Chodd, Maud has been so impatient, (the Chodds do not see Sidney—to Chodd, Sen.) I shall take your arm, Mr. Chodd. (very sweetly) Maud, dear; Mr. John will escort you.

div.stage: (street band heard playing "Fra Poco" Aria from Donizettis' Lucia di Lammermoor (1835); H.J. Byron's burlesque version acconmpanied the London performance at the Prince of Wales on 11/11/1865 "in distance— Maud takes Chodd, Jun's arm—the two couples go off, R. gate—as Maud turns, she looks an adieu at Sidney, who waves the bunch of ribbon, and sits down on chair in a reverie, not perceiving Lord Ptarmigant's legs — Lord Ptarmigant jumps up with pain—Sidney apologizes—Curtain quick)

Scene first.—Parlour at the "Owl's Roost" Public House. Cushioned seats all round the apartment; gas lighted R. and L., over tables; splint boxes, pipes, newspapers, fyc, on table ; writing materials on R. table (near door); gong bell on L. table; door of entrance, c. ; clock above door (hands set to half-past nine) ; hat pegs and hats on walls.

In the chair, at L. table head, is discovered O'Sullivan— also in the following order Mac Usquebaugh, Author, and Dr. Makvicz—also at R. table Trodnon (at head), Shamheart, Bradley, Scargil — the Reporter of "Belgravian Banner" is sitting outside the R. table, near
the head, and with his back turned to it, smoking a cigar —the Characters are all discovered drinking and smoking, some reading, some with their hats on.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Bravo ! hear—hear! bravo!

sp.speaker: O'Sull.
sp.p: (on his legs, a glass in one hand, and terminating a speech, in Irish accent) It is, therefore, gintlemen, with the most superlative felicitee, the most fraternal convivialitee, the warmest congenialitee, the most burning friendship, and ardent admiration, that I propose his health!

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Hear! hear, &c.

sp.speaker: O'Sull.
sp.p: He is a man, in the words of the divine bard

sp.speaker: Trod.
sp.p: (in sepulchral voice) Hear ! hear !

sp.speaker: O'Sull.
sp.p: Who, in "suffering everything, has suffered nothing."Hamlet II.2 (nearly)

sp.speaker: Trod.
sp.p: Hear! hear!

sp.speaker: O'Sull.
sp.p: I have known him, when in the days of his prosperitee, he rowled down to the House of Commons in his carriage.

sp.speaker: Mac U.
sp.p: 'Twasn't his own—'twas a job !

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Silence! chair! order!

sp.speaker: O'Sull.
sp.p: I have known him when his last copper, and his last glass of punch has been shared with the frind of his heart!

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Hear! hear!

sp.speaker: O'Sull.
sp.p: And it is with feelings of no small pride that I inform ye, that that frind of his heart was the humble individual who has now the honour to address ye !

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Hear! hear, &c.

sp.speaker: O'Sull.
sp.p: But prizeman at Trinity, mimber of the bar, sinator, classical scholar, or frind, Desmond Mac Usquebaugh has always been the same—a gintleman and a scholar; and that highest type of that glorious union— an Irish gintleman and scholar. Gintlemen, I drink his health. Desmond, my long loved frind, bless ye ! (all rise solemnly and drink—" Mr. Mac Usquebaugh."

sp.speaker: O'Sull.
sp.p: Gintlemen, my frind Mr. Mac Usquebaugh will respond.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Hear! hear!
sp.stage: Enter Waiter, with glasses, tobacco, &c, and receives orders—changes O'Sullivan's glass and exit, c.—Enter Tom Stylus and Chodd, Jun., C.—Tom has a great coat on over an evening dress.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: Thank you ; no, not anything.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Just a wet—an outrider—or advanced guard, to prepare the way for the champagne.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: No.
sp.stage: (as soon as the sitters see Tom Stylus they give him a friendly nod, look enquiringly at Chodd, and whisper each other)

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: (r.) You'd better. They are men worth knowing. (pointing them out) That is the celebrated Olinthus O'Sullivan, Doctor of Civil Laws. (O'sullivan is at this moment reaching to the gas light to light his pipe)

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: (L.) The gent with the long pipe ?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Yes; one of the finest classical scholars in the world ; might have sat upon the woolsack if he'd chosen but he didn't. (O'Sullivan is now tossing with Mac Usquebaugh) That is the famous Desmond Mac Usquebaugh, late M.P. for Killcrackskullcoddy, county Galway, a great patriot and orator; might have been Chancellor of the Exchequer if he'd chosen, but he didn't. (Scargil reaches to the gas light to light his pipe) That's Bill Bradley, (pointing to Bradley, who is reading paper with double eye-glass) author of the famous romance of "Time and Opportunity;" ran through ten editions. He got two thousand pounds for it, which was his ruin.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: How was he ruined by getting two thousand pounds?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: He's never done anything since. We call him "one book Bradley." That gentleman fast asleep— (looking towards author at table, L.) has made the fortune of three publishers, and the buttoned-up one with the shirt front of beard is Herr Makvicz, the great United German. Dr. Scargil, there, discovered the mensuration of the motive power of the cerebral organs. (Scargil takes pinch of snuff from a box on table)

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: How many million miles per minute thought can travel. He might have made his fortune if he'd chosen.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: But he didn't. Who is that mild looking party, with the pink complexion, and the white hair? (looking towards Shamheart)

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Sam Shamheart, the professional philanthropist. He makes it his business and profit to love the whole human race. (Shamheart puffs a huge cloud of smoke from his pipe) Smoke, sir; all smoke. A superficial observer would consider him only a pleasant oily humbug, but I, having known him two and twenty years, feel qualified to pronounce him one of the biggest villains untransported.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: And that man asleep at the end of the table ?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Trodnon, the eminent tragedian. (Trodnon raises himself from the table — yawns — stretches himself, and again drops head on table)

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: I never heard of him.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Nor anybody else. But he's a confirmed tippler, and here we consider drunkenness an infallible sign of genius—we make that a rule.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: But if they are all such great men, why didn't they make money by their talents?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: (R.) Make money! They'd scorn it! they wouldn't do it—that's another rule. That gentleman there (looking towards a very seedy man with eye-glass in his eye) does the evening parties on the "Belgravian Banner."

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: (with interest) Does he? Will he put my name in among the fashionables to-night ?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: And that we may know who's there and everything about it—you're going with me.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Yes, I'm going into society; thanks to your getting me the invitation. I can dress up an account, not a mere list of names, but a picturesque report of the Soiree, and shew under what brilliant auspices you entered the beau-monde.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: Beau-monde. What's that?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: (chaffing him) Every man is called a cockney who is born within the sound of the beau-monde.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: (not seeing it) Oh! Order me 200 copies of the "Belgravian" What's its name ?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: "Banner."

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: The day my name's in it—and put me down as a regular subscriber. I like to encourage high class literature. By the way, shall I ask the man what he'll take to drink ?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: No, no.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: I'll pay for it. I'll stand, you know. (going to him, Tom stops him)

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: No, no—he don't know you, and he'd be offended.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: But, I suppose all these chaps are plaguy poor?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Yes, they're poor; but they are gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: (grinning) I like that notion—a poor gentleman—it tickles me. (going up, R.)

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: (crossing into L. corner) Metallic snob !

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: I'm off now. (going up, R.) You'll come to my rooms and we'll go together in the brougham. I want to introduce you to my friends Lady Ptarmigant and Lord Ptarmigant?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: I must wait here for a proof I expect from the office.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: How long shall you be ?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: (looking at clock) An hour.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: Don't be later.
sp.stage: (Exit Chodd, Jun., C.—the Reporter rises, gets paper from, L , table, and shews it to Shamheart, sitting next him on his L. hand)

sp.speaker: O'Sull.
sp.p: Sit down, Tommy, my dear boy. Gintlemen, Mr. Desmond Mac Usquebaugh will respond, (tapping with hammer)
sp.stage: Enter Waiter, C, and gives Bradley a glass of grog.

sp.speaker: Mac U.
sp.p: (rising) Gintlemen. (Tom taking his coat off, shews evening dress)

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: A go of whiskey.

sp.speaker: Waiter.
sp.p: Scotch or Irish?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Irish.
sp.stage: Exit Waiter, C.—all are astonished at Tom's costume—they cry " by Jove ! there's a swell," &c.

sp.speaker: O'Sull.
sp.p: Why, Tom, my dear friend—are ye going to be married to-night, that ye're got up so gorgeously ?

sp.speaker: Mac U.
sp.p: Tom, you're handsome as an angel.

sp.speaker: O'Sull.
sp.p: Or a duke's footman. Gentlemen, rise and salute our illustrious brother.
sp.stage: (all rise and make Tom mock bows)

sp.speaker: Bead.
sp.p: The gods preserve you, noble sir.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: May the bill of your sublime highness' washerwoman be never the less.

sp.speaker: Mac U.
sp.p: And may it be paid, (a general laugh)

sp.speaker: O'Sull.
sp.p: Have you come into a fortune ?

sp.speaker: Dr. M.
sp.p: Or married a widow?

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: Or buried a relation ? (a general laugh) By my soul, Tom, you look an honour to humanity!

sp.speaker: O'Sull.
sp.p: And your laundress, (a general laugh)

sp.speaker: Bead.
sp.p: Gentlemen, Mr. Stylus's health and shirt front.
sp.stage: (a general laugh—all drink and sit)

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: (C.) Bless ye, my people, bless ye ! (sits, and takes out short pipe and smokes)

sp.speaker: O'Sull.
sp.p: Gentlemen, (rising) My friend, Mr.Usquebaugh, will respond.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Hear, hear!

sp.speaker: Mac U.
sp.p: (rising) Gentlemen —
sp.stage: Enter Sidney, in evening dress and wrapper. Enter Waiter with Tom's grog.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Hallo, Daryl!

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: How are ye, boys ? Doctor, how goes it ? (shaking hands) Mac. How d'ye do, O'Sullivan? Tom, I want to speak to you.

sp.speaker: O'Sull.
sp.p: Ah, Tom, this is the rale metal—the genuine thing; compared to him you are a sort of Whitechapel would-if-I-could-be. (to Sidney) Sit down, my gorgeous one, and drink with me.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: No, thanks. (Sidney and Tom sit at R. table head)

sp.speaker: O'Sull.
sp.p: Waiter, take Mr. Daryl's orders.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Brandy cold. Exit Waiter, c.

sp.speaker: Mac. U.
sp.p: Take off your wrap-rascal, and shew your fine feathers.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: No ; I'm going out, and I shall smoke my coat.
sp.stage: (Tom extinguishes his pipe, and puts it in his dress coat pocket, then puts on his great coat, with great solemnity)

sp.speaker: O'Sull.
sp.p: Going?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: O'Sull.
sp.p: Got the rheumatism ?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: No ; but I shall smoke my coat, (general laugh)
sp.stage: Enter Waiter, C.—he gives glass of brandy and water to Sidney, and glass of grog to Shamheart.

sp.speaker: O'Sull.
sp.p: What news, Daryl?

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: None, except that the Ministry is to be defeated. (O'Sullivan pays Waiter)

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: No!

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: I say, yes. They're whipping up everybody to vote against Thunder's motion. Thunder is sure of a majority, and out they go. Capital brandy, (coming forward) Tom! (Tom rises—they come down stage) I am off to a soiree.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: (r.—aside) So am I; but I won't tell him.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: (L.)I find I've nothing in my portmonnaie but notes. I want a trifle for a cab. Lend me five shillings.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: I haven't got it; but I can get it for you.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: There's a good fellow, do. (returns to seat)

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: (to Mac Usquebaugh, after looking round) Mac, (whispering) lend me five bob.

sp.speaker: Mac U.
sp.p: My dear boy, I haven't got so much.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Then don't lend it.

sp.speaker: Mac U.
sp.p: But I'll get it for you. (crosses to Bradley— whispers) Bradley, lend me five shillings.

sp.speaker: Brad.
sp.p: I haven't it about me; but I'll get it for you. (crosses to O'Sullivan—whispers) O'Sullivan, lend me five shillings.

sp.speaker: O'Sull.
sp.p: I haven't got it; but I'll get it for you. (crossing to Scargil—whispers) Scargil, lend me five shillings.

sp.speaker: Scarg.
sp.p: I haven't got it, but I'll get it for you. (crossing to Makvicz—whispers) Doctor, lend me five shillings.

sp.speaker: Dr. M.
sp.p: I am waiting for chaange vor a zoveren; I'll give it you when de waiter brings it me.

sp.speaker: Scarg.
sp.p: All right! (to O'Sullivan) All right!

sp.speaker: O'Sull.
sp.p: All right! (to Bradley) All right!

sp.speaker: Brad.
sp.p: All right! (to Mac Usquebaugh) All right!

sp.speaker: Mac U.
sp.p: All right! (to Tom) All right!

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: (to Sidney) All right !

sp.speaker: O'Sull.
sp.p: (tapping) Gentlemen, my friend Mr. Mac Usquebaugh will respond to the toast that

sp.speaker: Mac U.
sp.p: (rising) Gentlemen —

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Oh, cut the speechifying, I hate it! you ancients are so fond of spouting; let's be jolly, I've only a few minutes more.

sp.speaker: Brad.
sp.p: Daryl, sing us "Cock-a-doodle doo."

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: I only know the first two verses.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: I know the rest.
sp.stage: Enter Waiter, gives glass of grog to Makvicz.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Then here goes. Waiter, shut the door, and don't open it till I've done. Now then, ready.

div.stage: Exit Waiter—O'Sullivan taps.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.l: (giving out) Political:—
(sings) When ministers in fear and doubt, The Music of this Song is published by Metzler & Co., 37, Great Marlborough Street.
That they should be from place kicked out,
Get up 'gainst time and sense to spout
A long dull evening through.
What mean they then by party clique,
Mob orators and factions weak ?
'Tis only would they truth then speak
But cock-a-doodle doo!
Cock-a-doodle, cock-a-doodle, cock-a-doodle doo.

sp.speaker: Chorus.
sp.l: (gravely and solemnly shaking their heads) Cock a-doodle, &c.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.l: (speaking) Commercial:—
When companies, whose stock of cash
Directors spend to cut a dash,
Are formed to advertise and smash,
And bankruptcy go through.
When tradesfolks live in regal state,
The goods they sell adulterate,
And puff in print, why what's their prate
But cock-a-doodle-doo?
Cock-a-doodle, cock-a-doodle, &c.

sp.speaker: Chorus.
sp.l: (as before) Cock-doodle, &c.

div.stage: Enter Waiter, C.

sp.speaker: O'Sull.
sp.p: How dare you come in and interrupt the harmony ?

sp.speaker: Waiter.
sp.p: Beg pardon, sir, but there's somebody says as he must see Mr. Stylus.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Is he a devil ?

sp.speaker: Waiter.
sp.p: No, sir, he's a juvenile, (a general laugh)

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Send in some whiskey—Irish—and the devil.

sp.speaker: Waiter.
sp.p: Hot, sir ? (a general laugh)
sp.stage: Tom nods to Waiter who exits, C. door.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Why can't you see your proofs at the office ?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: I'm in full fig, and can't stew in that atmosphere of steam and copperas.
sp.stage: Enter Printer's Boy, C, he goes up to Tom at head of R. table—Enter Waiter with tray, hot water jug, &c.—he gives change in silver to Makvicz who crosses to Scargil —Waiter puts hot water jug and whiskey before Tom, and exit C. door.

sp.speaker: Doctor M.
sp.p: Here ! (giving two half crowns to Scargil) Scargil!

sp.speaker: Scarg.
sp.p: (crossing in same manner to O' Sullivan) Here, O'Sullivan !

sp.speaker: O'Sull.
sp.p: (crossing to Bradley) Here, Bradley.

sp.speaker: Brad.
sp.p: (crossing to Mac Usquebaugh) Here, Mac.

sp.speaker: Mac U.
sp.p: (crossing to Tom) Here, Tom.

sp.speaker: Printer's Boy.
sp.p: (to Tom) Please, sir, Mr. Duval said would you add this to it ? (giving Tom a proof slip)

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: All right—wait outside—I'll bring it to you. Exit Boy,c.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.stage: (draws writing pad towards him—takes his grog, and is about to pour hot water from pewter jug into it, when he burns his fingers, starts up and dances)
sp.p: Confound it!

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: I've scalded my fingers with the hot water.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: (taking up pen) Here, I'll correct it for you.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Thank you.

sp.speaker: O'Sull.
sp.p: Gintlemen, proceed with the harmony. Mr. Stylus

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: One minute, (to Sidney) Just add this to it.
sp.stage: (Sidney sits down to write, Tom standing over him)

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: (reading slip) "Fashionable Intelligence.—We hear a marriage is on the tapis between Mr. John Chodd, junior, son of the celebrated millionaire, and Miss Maud Hetherington, daughter of the late Colonel Hetherington." (Sidney starts)

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: What's the matter ?

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Nothing! (he goes on writing—O'Sullivan taps hammer)

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: (speaking) Amatory :—
(sings) When woman, lovely woman sighs,
You praise her form, her hair, her eyes;
Would link your heart by tend'rest ties,
And vow your vows are true.
She answers tenderly and low,
Though from her lips the words that flow,
So softly sweet are nought we know
But cock-a-doodle-doo !

div.stage: (Tom throws the five shillings to Sidney, which rattle on the table—Sidney gives him lack the proof, his face is deadly pale—as his head falls on the table the Chorus is singing, "Cock-a-doodle-doo, &c."—closed in)

Scene Second.—A Retiring Room at " Sir Farintosh Fadileaf's " (2nd grooves) ; large archway or alcove, L., with curtain drawn or doors leading to ball room ; small arch or alcove, R., leading to supper room, with drawn curtain ; centre opening curtains drawn ; the room is decorated for a ball; candelabra, flowers, &c

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: (without) Very pretty—very pretty indeed, Sir Farintosh; all very nice.
sp.stage: Enter from R., with Sir Farintosh, Lord Ptarmigant and Maud, all in evening dress.

sp.speaker: Sir F.
sp.p:
(an old beau) So kind of you, cousin The lines between inverted commas can be omitted.
Ptarmigant, to take pity on a poor old widower who has no womankind to receive for him, and all that.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Not at all—not at all; I am only too glad to be useful.

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: (speaking off, R. 1 e.) Bring chairs.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Ferdinand, you can't want to go to sleep again!

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: I know I can't, but I do.

p.stage: (Servant brings two chairs and a small table, R.)

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Besides I don't want chairs here, young men get lolling about, and then they don't dance. (Lord Ptarmigant sits, R., and closes his eyes) Farintosh, (knocks heard) the arrivals are beginning.

sp.speaker: Sir F.
sp.p: But, Lady Ptarmigant, if --

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Remember that the old Dowager Countess of Mc Swillumore has plenty of whiskey toddy in a green glass, to make believe hock.

sp.speaker: Sir F.
sp.p: But if --

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Now go. Oh dear me! (almost forces Sir Farintosh off, L.)Now, Maud, one word with you; you have been in disgrace all this last week about that writing fellow.

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: (L., indignant) What writing fellow ?

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Don't echo me if you please. You know who I mean—Daryl!

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: Mr. Daryl is a relation of your ladyship's—the son of the late Sir Percy Daryl, and brother of the present Baronet.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: (r.) And when the present Baronet, that precious Percy, squandered everything at the gaming table, dipped the estates, and ruined himself, Sidney gave up the money left him by his mother, to reinstate a dissolute beggared brother ! don't forget that !

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: (with exaltation) I do not forget it, I never shall. To give up all his fortune, to ruin his bright prospects to preserve his brother, and his brother's wife and children, to keep unsullied the honour of his name, was an act ——

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p:
Of a noodle, and now he hasn't a penny save what he gets by scribbling—a pretty pass for a man of family to come to. You are my niece, and it is
my solemn duty to get you married if I can. Don't thwart me, and I will. Leave sentiment to servant wenches who sweetheart the policeman, it's unworthy of a lady. I've a man in my eye—I mean a rich one—young Chodd.

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: (with repugnance) Such a common-place person.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: With a very uncommon-place purse. He will have eighteen thousand a year. I have desired him to pay you court, and I desire you to receive it.

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: He is so vulgar.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: He is so rich. When he is your husband put him in a back study, and don't shew him.

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: But I detest him.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: What on earth has that to do with it ? You wouldn't love a man before you were married to him, would you ? Where are your principles ? Ask my lord how I treated him before our marriage, (hitting Lord P. with her fan) Ferdinand!

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: (awaking) My love!

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Do keep awake.

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: 'Pon my word you were making such a noise I thought I was in the House of Commons, (with fond regret) I used to be allowed to sleep so comfortably there.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Are you not of opinion that a match between Mr. Chodd and Maud would be most desirable.

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: (looking at Lady P.) Am I not of opinion— my opinion—what is my opinion ?

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: (hitting him with fan) Yes, of course.

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: Yes—of course—my opinion is yes, of course. (aside—crossing C. with chair) Just as it used to be in the house. I always roused in time to vote as I was told to.

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: But, uncle, one can't purchase happiness at shops in packets, like bon-bons. A thousand yards of lace cost so much, they can be got at the milliner's; but an hour of home or repose can only be had for love. Mere wealth —

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: My dear, wealth, if it does not bring happiness, brings the best imitation of it procurable for money. There are two things—wealth and poverty. The former makes the world a place to live in; the latter a place to— go to sleep in—-as I do. (leans back in chair and dozes)

div.stage: Enter Sir Farintosh, Colonel Browser and LordCloudwrays, L. C.

sp.speaker: Sir F.
sp.p: Have you heard the news? the division is to come off to-night. Many men won't be able to come. I must be off to vote. If the Ministry go out

sp.speaker: Col. B.
sp.p: They won't go out—there'll be a dissolution!

sp.speaker: Sir F.
sp.p: And I shall have to go down to be re-elected. Cloudwrays, will you come and vote?

sp.speaker: Lord C.
sp.p: (languidly) No.

sp.speaker: Sir F.
sp.p: Why not?

sp.speaker: Lord C.
sp.p: I'm dying for a weed.

sp.speaker: Sir F.
sp.p: You can smoke in the smoking room!

sp.speaker: Lord C.
sp.p: So I can—that didn't occur to me!

sp.speaker: Sir F.
sp.p: Ptarmigant, cousin, you do the honours for me. My country calls, you know, and all that. Come on, Cloudwrays; how slow you are. Hi, tobacco !
sp.stage: (Cloudwrays rouses himself—exeunt Sir Farintosh and Lord Cloudwrays—Lord Ptarmigant dozes)

sp.speaker: Col. B.
sp.p: (who has been talking to Lady Ptarmigant, turns to Lord Ptarmigant)As I was saying to her ladyship ——

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Ferdinand, do wake up !

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: Hear, hear! (waking) My dear!"
Enter Servant, R. 1 E.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Mr. Chodd, Mr. John Chodd and Mr. Stylus.
sp.stage: Enter Chodd, Jun., Chodd, Sen. and Tom, R. 1 E.—exit Servant, R. I E.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: (L. C. ) My dear Mr. Chodd, how late you are! Maud dear, here is Mr. Chodd. Do you know we were going to scold you, you naughty men!

sp.speaker: Chodd, Sen.
sp.p: (r. c, astonished—aside) Naughty men ! Johnny, her ladyship says we're naughty men; we've done something wrong!

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p:
(r.) No, no—it's only her Ladyship's patrician fun. Don't call me Johnny—I'm sure I hurried here on the wings of — (crossing L. c, falls over Lord Ptarmigant's feet, who rises and turns his chair the
reverse way—Chodd seeing Maud, repellant)—a brougham and pair. Lady Ptarmigant, let me introduce a friend of mine. Lady Ptarmigant—Mr. Stylus, whom I took the liberty of ——

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Charmed to see any friend of yours!
sp.stage: (Tom advances from back, R., abashed—as he is backing and bowing he falls over Lord Ptarmigant's legs—Lord Ptarmigant rises with look of annoyance—they bow—Lord Ptarmigant again turns chair and sits)

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Mr. Chodd, take me to the ball room. (Chodd Sen., offers his arm) You will look after Maud, I'm sure. (to Chodd, Jun., who smilingly offers his arm to Maud, who with a suppressed look of disgust, takes it) Mr. Si-len-us.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Stylus—ma'am—my lady.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Stylus—pardon me—will you be kind enough to keep my lord awake? (significantly) Maud!— now, dear Mr. Chodd.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: "Guv !
sp.stage: Exeunt Lady Ptarmigant, Maud, and the Chodds, L.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: (aside) These are two funny old swells !

sp.speaker: Col. B.
sp.p: Odd looking fellow, (to Tom) Nice place this!

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Very.

sp.speaker: Col. B.
sp.p: And charming man, Fadileaf.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Very;—I don't know him, but I should say he must be very jolly.

sp.speaker: Col. B.
sp.p: (laughing) Bravo !—why you're a wit!

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Yes! (aside) What does he mean ?

sp.speaker: Col. B.
sp.p: (offering box) Snuff? Who's to win the Leger? Diadeste ?The English St Leger stakes is the oldest and final classic of the year which marks the end of the British flat racing season.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: I don't know,—not in my department.

sp.speaker: Col. B.
sp.p: (laughing) Very good.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: What is ? (innocently)

sp.speaker: Col. B.
sp.p: You are. Do you play whist ?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Yes,—cribbage and all fours, likewise.

sp.speaker: Col. B.
sp.p: We'll find another man, and make up a rubber.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: (pointing to Lord Ptarmigant asleep) He'll do for dummy.

sp.speaker: Col. B.
sp.p: (laughing) Capital!

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: What a queer fellow this is,—he laughs at everything I say. (dance music)

sp.speaker: Col. B.
sp.p: They've begun.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: (waking up Lord Ptarmigant) My lady said I was to keep you awake.

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: Thank you.

sp.speaker: Col. B.
sp.p: Come and have a rubber! Let's go and look up Chedbury.

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Col. B.
sp.p: (to Tom) You'll find us in the card room.
sp.stage: Exeunt Lord Ptarmigant and Colonel Browser, L.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Ferdinand! (going up C. to Lord Ptarmigant, who awakes) Do rouse yourself, and follow me to the ball room.
sp.stage: Exeunt all but Tom, L. 2 E.—Lord Ptarmigant returns and drags chair off after him.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Here I am in Society, and I think Society is rather slow; it's much jollier at the "Owl," and there's more to drink. If it were not wicked to say it, how I should enjoy a glass of gin and water !
sp.stage: Enter Lady Ptarmigant, L.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: (L.) Mr. Si-len-us!

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: (r.—abashed) Stylus, ma'am—my lady!

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Stylus ! I beg pardon. You're all alone.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: With the exception of your ladyship !

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: All the members have gone down to the House to vote, and we are dreadfully in want of men— I mean dancers ! You dance, of course ?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Oh ! of course—I (abashed)

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: As it is Leap-year, I may claim the privilege of asking you to see me through a quadrille !

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: (R.—frightened) My lady! I

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: (L.—aside) He's a friend of the Chodds, and it will please them. Come then ! (she takes his arm)— (sniffing) Dear me ! What a dreadful smell of tobacco! (sniffing)

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: (awfully self-conscious—sniffing) Is there ?

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: (sniffing) Some fellow must have been smoking.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p:
(sniffing) I think some fellow must, or some
fellow must have been where some other fellows have been smoking, (aside) It's that beastly parlour at the "Owl." (in taking out his pocket handkerchief his pipe falls on floor)

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: What's that ? This incident is taken from M. Emile Augier's admirable comedy of "Les Effrontes".—T. W. R.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: (in torture) What's what? (turning about and looking through eye glass at the air)

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: (pointing) That!

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: (as if in doubt) I rather think—it—is—a pipe !

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: I'm sure of it. You'll join me in the ball room, (going up c. to L.)

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Instantly, your ladyship.
sp.stage: Exit Lady Ptarmigant, L.
(looking at pipe—he picks it up)
sp.p: If ever I bring you into society again (drops it) Waiter!
sp.stage: Enter Page, R. 1. E.
sp.p: Somebody's dropped something. Remove the whatsoname.
sp.stage: (Quadrille Music in ball room, Page goes off, R. 1. E. and returns with tray and sugar tongs, with which he picks up pipe with an air of ineffable disgust and goes off, R. 1. E.)
Now to spin round the old woman in the mazy waltz (splits kid gloves in drawing them on) there goes one and nine. Exit Tom, L.
Enter Sidney, L.—he is pale and excited—one of the gold links of his wrist-band is unfastened.

sp.speaker: Sid.
sp.p:
I have seen her—she was smiling—dancing, but not with him. She looked so bright and happy. I won't think of her. How quiet it is here: so different to that hot room with the crowd of fools and coquettes whirling round each other. I like to be alone—alone! I am now thoroughly—and to think it was but a week ago—one little week—I'll forget her—forget, and hate her:—Hate her—Oh, Maud; Maud; till now, I never knew how much I loved you; loved you—loved you—gone ; shattered ; shivered ; and for whom?—for one of my own birth? for one of my own rank ?—No ! for a common clown, who—
confound this link—but he is rich—and—it won't hold (trying to fasten it—his fingers trembling) I've heard it all—always with her, at the Opera and the Park attentive and obedient—and she accepts him. My head aches— (louder) I'll try a glass of champagne.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: (without, R.) Champagne—here you are! (draws curtain)
sp.stage: Enter Tom, R. 2 E., with champagne glass, from supper room—portion of supper table seen in alcove.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: (seeing Sidney) Sidney.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Tom ! you here !

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Very much here: (drinking) I was brought by Mr. Chodd.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: (L.) Chodd?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: (r.) Don't startle a fella. You look pale—aren't you well ?
Sidney, (rallying) Jolly, never better.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Have some salmon.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: I'm not hungry.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Then try some jelly, it's no trouble to masticate and is emollient and agreeable to the throat and palate.

sp.speaker: Sydney.
sp.p: No, Tom, champagne.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: There you are. (fetching bottle from table)

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: I'll meet her eye to eye. (drinks) Another, Tom—and be as smiling and indifferent. As for that heavy-metalled dog—thanks, Tom. (drinks) Another.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: I've been drinking with old Lady Ptarmigant. Sidney. Confound her.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: I did. As I was twirling her round I sent my foot through her dress and tore her skirt out of the gathers.
Sidney, (laughing hysterically) Good! good! bravo ! Tom ! Did she row you ?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Not a bit. She said it was of no consequence; but her looks were awful.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Ha! ha ! ha! Tom you're a splendid fellow, not like these damned swells, all waistcoat and shirt front.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p:
But I like the swells. I played a rubber with them and won three pounds, then I shewed them some conjuring tricks—you know I'm a famous conjuror (taking
a pack of cards out of his pocket) By Jupiter! look here I've brought the pack away with me ; I didn't know I had. I'll go and take it back.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: (taking cards from him absently) No, never mind, stay with me, I don't want you to go.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: I find high life most agreeable, everybody is so amiable, so thoughtful, so full of feeling.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Feeling! Why man, this is a flesh market where the matchmaking mammas and chattering old chaperons have no more sense of feeling than drovers--- the girls no more sentiment than sheep, and the best man is the highest bidder; that is, the biggest fool with the longest purse.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Sidney, you're ill.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: You lie, Tom—never better—excellent high spirits—confound this link !
sp.stage: Enter Lord Cloudwrays

sp.speaker: Lord C.
sp.p: By Jove! Ha, Sidney, heard the news ?

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: (C.)News—there is no news! the times are bankrupt, and the assignees have sold off the events.

sp.speaker: Lord C.
sp.p: The Ministry is defeated.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Lord C.
sp.p: Yes; by a majority of forty-six.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Serve them right.

sp.speaker: Lord C.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: I don't know ! Why, what a fellow you are to want reasons.

sp.speaker: Lord C.
sp.p: Sidney!

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Hollo, Cloudwrays ! my bright young British senator—my undeveloped Chatham, and mature Raleigh.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Will they resign ?

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Of course they will: resignation is the duty of every man, or minister, who can't do anything else.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Who will be sent for to form a government ?

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Cloudwrays.

sp.speaker: Lord C.
sp.p: How you do chaff a man!

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Why not? Inaugurate a new policy —the policy of smoke—free trade in tobacco! Go in, not for principles, but for PrincipesA brand of flavoured cigar—our hearths—our homes, and 'bacca-boxes!

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: If there's a general election ?

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Hurrah, for a general election ! eh, Cloudwrays — What speeches you'll make—what lies you'll tell, and how your constituents won't believe you!

sp.speaker: Lord C.
sp.p: How odd you are.

sp.speaker: Lord C.
sp.p: Arn't you well?

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Glorious ! only one thing annoys me.

sp.speaker: Lord C.
sp.p: What's that ?

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: They won't give me any more champagne.

sp.speaker: Lord C.
sp.p: Lady Ptarmigant sent me here to say the ladies want partners.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Partners! Here are partners for them—long, tall, stout, fat, thin, poor, rich, (crossing, c.) Cloudwrays, you're the man!
sp.stage: Enter Chodd, Jun., L.—Sidney sees and points to him.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: No ; this is the man !

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: (L.) Confound this fellow ! (aside)

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: (L. C. ) This, sir, is the "Young Lady's Best Companion," Perhaps a reference to Margaret Coxe's "The young lady's companion in a series of letters" (1839); "I'd sooner read The Young Lady's Best Companion than that stupid mawkish trash! ("The wooing and the winning of Amy O'Neill", Dublin 1850 p.446) ; but there are many similar titles. well bound, Bramah-locked,https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bramah_lock and gilt at the edges—mind, gilt only at the edges. This link will not hold, (sees the pack of cards in his hand) Here, Chodd, take these—no, cut for a ten pound note, (puts cards on small table, R.)

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: (L. C, quickly) With pleasure, (aside) I'll punish this audacious pauper in the pocket, (crossing to table)

sp.speaker: Lord C.
sp.p: You mustn't gamble here.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Only for a frolic !

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: I'm always lucky at cards!

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Yes, I know an old proverb about that.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: Eh?

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: (R.) Lucky at play, unlucky in —— This link will not hold.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: (L. C. , maliciously) Shall we put the stakes down first?

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: (producing portmonnaie) With pleasure!

sp.speaker: Lord C.
sp.p: But I don't think it right (advancing— Chodd stays him with his arm)

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Sidney!

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Nonsense! hold your tongue, Cloudwrays, and I'll give you a regalia. Let's make it for five-and-twenty?

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: Done!

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Lowest wins—that's in your favour.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: Eh?

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Ace is lowest, (they cut) Mine ! Double the stakes ?

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: Done! (they cut)

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Mine again ! Double again?

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: Done ! (they cut)

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: You're done again! I'm in splendid play to-night. One hundred I think!

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: I'd play again (handing notes) but I've no more with me.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Your word's sufficient—you can send to my chambers—besides, you've got your cheque book. A hundred again ?

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: Yes. (they cut)

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Huzzah! Fortune's a lady! Again? (Chodd nods—they cut) Bravo ! Again ? (Chodd nods—they cut) Mine again! Again? (Chodd nods—they cut) Mine again! Again ? (Chodd nods—they cut) Same result! That makes five! Let's go in for a thousand?

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: Done!

sp.speaker: Lord C.
sp.p: (advancing) No!

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: (savagely) Get out of the way! (Lord Cloudwrays looks at him through eye glass in astonishment)

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Pooh! (they cut) Mine ! Double again ?

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lord C.
sp.p: (going round to back of table and seizing the pack) No ; I can't suffer this to go on—Lady Ptarmigant would be awful angry, (going off, L.)

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Here, Cloudwrays! what a fellow you are. Exit Lord Cloudwrays, L. C.
(turning to Chodd, Jun.) You owe me a thousand !

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: I shall not forget it.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: I don't suppose you will. Confound—(trying to button sleeve link, crossing c.) Oh, to jog your memory, take this, (gives him sleeve link, which he has been trying to button, and goes off after Lord Cloudwrays, L. C.)

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: And after I have paid you, I'll remember and clear off the old score.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: (R., taking his arm as he is going) Going into the ball room ?

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: (L., aghast at his intrusion) Yes!

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: (r.) I'll go with you.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: (L., disengaging his arm) I'm engaged !
sp.stage: Exit Chodd, L. Music till end.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: You've an engaging manner! I'm like a donkey between two bundles of hay. On one side woman—lovely woman! on the other, wine and wittles. (taking out a sovereign) Heads, supper—tails, the ladies—(tosses at table) Supper! sweet goddess Fortune, accept my thanks!
sp.stage: Exit into supper room, R.
Enter Maud and Chodd, Jun., L.

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: (L.) This dreadful man follows me about everywhere.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: (R.) My dear Miss Hetherington!

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: I danced the last with you.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: That was a quadrille.
sp.stage: Enter Sidney, L.
sp.p: This is for a polka.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: (advancing between them) The lady is engaged to me.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: This fellow's turned up again, (to him) I beg your pardon.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: I beg yours! I have a prior claim, (bitterly)Ask the lady—or perhaps I had better give her up to you.

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: The next dance with you, Mr. Chodd, this one—

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: Miss, your commands are acts of Parliament, (looking spitefully at Sidney as he crosses, L.) I'll go and see what Lady Ptarmigant has to say to this.
sp.stage: Exit Chodd, Junior, L.—Music changes to a slow waltz.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Listen to me for the last time. My life and being were centred in you. You have abandoned me for money. You accepted me; you now throw me off, for money! You pledged your faith you now break it, for money! You gave your hand, you now retract, for money ! You are about to wed—a knave, a brute, a fool, whom in your own heart you despise, for money!

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: How dare you ?

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Where falsehood is, shame cannot be. The last time we met, (producing ribbon) you gave me this. See, 'tis the colour of a man's heart's blood, (curtains or doors at back draw apart) I give it back to you. (casting the bunch of ribbon at her feet)
sp.stage: Lord Cloudwrays, Tom, Lord Ptarmigant, and Lady Ptarmigant, Chodd, Junior, and Chodd, Senior, appear at back— Guests seen in ball room.
sp.p: And tell you, shameless girl, much as I once loved, and adored, I now despise and hate you.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: (advancing, c, in a whisper to Sidney) Leave the house, sir ! How dare you—go !

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Yes; anywhere.

div.stage: (crash of Music—Maud is nearly falling when Chodd, Jun., appears near her—she is about to lean on his arm, but recognizing him, retreats and staggers —Sidney is seen to reel through ball room full of dancers—drop)
Guests. Sidney. Cloudwrays. "Sir F." Tom. " Col. B." Lord P. Chodd, SeN Lady P. Chodd, Jon. Maud.
Scene first.—" The Owl's Roost." (same as Scene 1st Act 2nd,), daylight—the room in order.

Tom discovered writing at table, R., Boy sitting on table, L., and holding the placards, on which is printed—"Read the Morning Earthquake—a first-class daily Paper," &c. On the other "The Evening Earthquake—a first-class daily Paper—Latest Intelligence," &c.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Um! It'll look well on the walls, and at the railway stations—take these back to the office (boy jumps down) to Mr. Piker, and tell him he must wait for the last leader—till it's written.
sp.stage: Exit Boy, C, Tom walks to and fro smoking long clay pipe.
sp.p:
The M.E.—that is, the "Morning Earthquake" shakes the world for the first time to-morrow morning, and everything seems to have gone wrong with it. It is a crude unmanageable ill-disciplined, ill-regulated earthquake— Heave the first—Old Chodd behaves badly to me :—after organizing him a first-rate earthquake, engaging him a brilliant staff, and stunning reporters, he doesn't even offer me the post of sub-editor—ungrateful old humbug ! Heave the second:—no sooner is he engaged than our editor is laid up with the gout—and then old Chodd asks me to be a literary warming pan, and keep his place hot, till colchicumTreatment for gout derived from the autumn crocus and cold water have done their work—I'll be even with old Chodd though ! I'll teach him what it is to insult a man who has started eighteen daily and weekly papers—all of them failures. Heave the third—Sidney Daryl won't write the social leaders, (sits L. at end of R. table) Poor Sidney! (takes out the magenta ribbon which he picked up at the ball) I shan't dare to give him this—I picked it up at the ball, at which I was one of the distinguished, and illustrious guests. Love is an awful swindler—always drawing upon Hope, who never honours his draughts—a sort of whining beggar, continually moved on by the maternal police—but 'tis a weakness to which the wisest of us are subject—a kind of manly measles which this flesh is heir to, particularly when
the flesh is heir to nothing else—even I have felt the divine damnation—I mean emanation. But the lady united herself to another, which was a very good thing for me, and anything but a misfortune for her: Ah ! happy days of youth—Oh ! flowering fields of Runnington-cum- Wapshot—where the yellow corn waved, our young loves ripened, and the new jail now stands. Oh ! Sally,when I think of you and the past, I feel that (looking into his pot) the pot's empty, and I could drink another pint. (putting the ribbon in his pocket) Poor Sidney—I'm afraid he's going to the bad.
sp.stage: Enter Sidney, C. he strikes bell on L. table and sits at the head—his appearance altered.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Ha! Sid, is that you? talk of the howdedo?

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Quite well—how are you?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: I'm suffering from an earthquake in my head— and a general printing office in my stomach. Have some beer?
sp.stage: Enter Waiter, C.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: No thanks—brandy

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: So early ?

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: And soda. I didn't sleep last night.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Brandy and soda, and beer again.
sp.stage: Exit Waiter, with pint pot off R. table.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: I never do sleep now—I can't sleep.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Work hard.
sp.stage: Enter Waiter, C.

sp.speaker: Sid.
sp.p: I do—it is my only comfort—my old pen goes driving along at the rate of — (Waiter after placing pint of porter before Tom— places tray with brandy and soda before Sidney) That's right! (Waiter uncorks soda and Exit, c.) What a splendid discovery was brandy, (drinks)

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Yes, the man who invented it deserves a statue.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: That's the reason that he doesn't get one.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: (reading paper) Election intelligence. There's the general election—why not go in for that.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Election—pooh ! what do I care for that!

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Nothing of course, but it's occupation.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: (musing) I wonder who'll put up for Springmead!

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Your brother's seat, wasn't it ?

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Yes, our family's for years. By-the-way, I'd a letter from Percy last mail; he's in trouble, poor fellow —his little boy is dead, and he himself is in such ill-health that they have given him sick leave. We are an unlucky race, we Daryls. Sometimes, Tom, I wish that I were dead.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Sidney!

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: It's a bad wish I know; but what to me is there worth living for ?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: What! oh, lots of things. Why, there's the police reports—mining intelligence—hop districts—the tallow market—ambition—society !

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: (heartily) Damn society !

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: And you know, Sid, there are more women in the world than one.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: But only one a man can love.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: I don't know about that: temperaments differ.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.stage: (pacing about and reciting)
sp.l: "As the husband, so the wife is.
"Thou art mated to a clown :
And the grossness of his nature
Shall have power to drag thee down ;
He will hold thee when his passion
Shall have spent its novel force,
Something better than his dog, and
Little dearer than his horse."
sp.p: I'm ashamed of such a want of spirit—ashamed to be such a baby! And you, Tom, are the only man in the world I'd shew it to; but I—I can think of nothing else but her—and—and of the fate in store for her. (sobs and leans on table with his face in his hands)

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Don't give way, Sid; there are plenty of things in this life to care for.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Not for me—not for me.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Oh, yes! there's friendship ; and—and—the little girl, you know!

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p:
That reminds me, I wrote a week ago to
Mrs. Churton, asking her to meet me with Mau—with the little darling in the square. I always asked them to come from Hampstead to the square, that I might look up at her window as I passed. What a fool I've been—I can't meet them this morning! Will you go for me ?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: With pleasure.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Give Mrs. Churton this, (wrapping up money in paper from Tom's case) It's the last month's money. Tell her I'm engaged, and can't come—and (putting down money) buy the baby a toy, bless her! What a pity to think she'll grow up to be a woman !
sp.stage: Enter Mac Usquebaugh, O'Sullivan, and Makvicz.

sp.speaker: Mac U.
sp.p: (entering) A three of whiskey, hot!

sp.speaker: O'Sull.
sp.p: The same for me—neat.

sp.speaker: Dr. M.
sp.p: A pint of stoot. (all sit, R.)

sp.speaker: O'Sull.
sp.p: Tom, mee boy, what news of the Earthquake ?
sp.stage: Enter Waiter with orders, and gives Tom a note.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Heaving, sir—heaving. (Tom opens note—Sidney sits abstracted) Who's going electioneering ?

sp.speaker: Dr. M.
sp.p: I am.

sp.speaker: O'Sull.
sp.p: And I.

sp.speaker: Mac. U.
sp.p: And so am I.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Mac U.
sp.p: I don't know.

sp.speaker: O'Sull.
sp.p: Somewhere—anywhere.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: (reading note) From Chodd, senior—the old villain! (reads) " Dear Sir,—Please meet me at Lady Ptarmigant's at eleven p.m." (suddenly) Sidney!

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: (moodily) What?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: (reading note) "I am off to Springmead-le-Beau by the train at two-fifty. My son, Mr. John Chodd, junior, is the candidate for the seat for the borough."

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: (rising) What !—that hound!—that cur!— that digesting cheque book—represent the town that my family have held their own for centuries. I'd sooner put up for it myself, (rising)

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: (rising) Why not? Daryl for Springmead— here's occupation—here's revenge !

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: By heaven, I will ! (crosses into R., and returns)

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: (c.) Gentlemen, the health of Mr. Daryl, M.P. for Springmead. (Sidney crosses to l.)

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: (rising and drinking) Hurrah!

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: We'll canvas for you. (aside) And now, Mr. Chodd, senior, I see the subject for the last leader. I'll fetter you with your own type, (down, L.)

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: (crosses, c.) I'll do it! I'll do it! When does the next train start ?

sp.speaker: Mac U.
sp.p: (taking Bradshaw https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bradshaw%27s_Guidefrom table, R.) At two-fifty—the next at five.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: (crossing to L.) Huzza! (with excitement) I'll rouse up the tenants—call on the tradesmen! (crossing to c.)

sp.speaker: O'Sull.
sp.p: But the money?

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: (c.) I'll fight him with the very thousand that I won of him. Besides, what need has a Daryl of money at Springmead ?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: We can write for you.

sp.speaker: O'Sull.
sp.p: (r. c.) And fight for you.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: I feel so happy—Call cabs.

sp.speaker: Mac U.
sp.p: How many?

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: The whole rank! (goes up, c.)

sp.speaker: Tom.
