sp.p: But, Sidney, what colours shall we fight under ?

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: What colours ? (feels in his breast and appears dejected—Tom hands him the ribbons—he clutches them eagerly) What colours?—magenta!

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Huzzah! (closed in as they go up) *

div.stage: Scene Second.—An Apartment at Lord Ptarmigant's. (1st grooves).
A chair brought on by Page, R. 1 E.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: (without, L. 1 E.) Good-bye, dear Mr. Chodd. A pleasant ride, and all sorts of success.
sp.stage: Enter Lady Ptarmigant, L. 1 E.
sp.p:
Phew! there's the old man gone. Now to speak to that
* O'Sullivan. Sidney. Mac Usquebaugh. Tom. Makvicz. stupid Maud, (looking off, R.) There she sits in the sulks —a fool! Ah, what wise folks the French were before the Revolution, when there was a Bastile or a convent in which to pop dangerous young men and obstinate young women, (sweetly) Maud dear! I'll marry her to young Chodd, I'm determined.
sp.stage: Enter Maud, R. 1 E., very pensive.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Maud, I wish to speak to you.

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: Upon what subject, aunt?

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: (L.) One that should be very agreeable to a girl of your age—marriage.

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: (R.) Mr. Chodd again.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Yes, Mr. Chodd again.

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: I hate him!

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: You wicked thing! How dare you use such expressions in speaking of a young gentleman so rich?

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: Gentleman!

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Yes, gentleman !—at least he will be.

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: Nothing can make Mr. Chodd—what a name! —anything but what he is.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Money can do everything.

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: Can it make me love a man I hate ?

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Yes ; at least, if it don't it ought. I suppose you mean to marry somebody?

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: You audacious girl! how can you talk so wickedly ? Where do you expect to go to ?

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: To needlework! Anything from this house; and from this persecution.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Miss Hetherington!

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: Thank you, Lady Ptarmigant. for calling me by my name ; it reminds me who I am, and of my dead father, "Indian Hetherington," as he was called. It reminds me that the protection you have offered to his orphan daughter has been hourly embittered by the dreadful temper, which is an equal affliction to you as to those within your reach. It reminds me that the daughter of such a father should not stoop to a mesalliance, (crossing to L.)

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p:
Mesalliance ! How dare you call Mr. Chodd
a mesalliance? And you hankering after that paltry, poverty-stricken, penny-a-liner!

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: Lady Ptarmigant, you forget yourself; and you are untruthful. Mr. Daryl is a gentleman by birth and breeding ! I loved him—I acknowledge it—I love him still!

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: You shameless girl! and he without a penny! After the scene he made !

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: He has dared to doubt me, and I have done with him for ever. From the moment he presumed to think that I could break my plighted word—that I could be false to the love I had acknowledged—the love that was my happiness and pride—all between us was over.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: (aside) That's some comfort, (aloud) Then what do you intend to do ?

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: I intend to leave the house.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: To go where ?

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: Anywhere from you!

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Upon my word! (aside) She has more spirit than I gave her credit for. (aloud) And do you mean to tell me that that letter is not intended for that fellow, Daryl?

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: (giving letter) Read it.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: (opens it and reads) "To the Editor of the 'Times.' Please insert the enclosed advertisement, for which I send stamps. Wanted a situation as governess by"—(embracing Maud) Oh, my dear—dear girl! you couldn't think of such a thing—and you a lady, and my niece.

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: (disengaging herself) Lady Ptarmigant, please don't!

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: (thoroughly subdued) But, my love, how could I think —

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: What, Lady Ptarmigant, thinks is a matter of the most profound indifference to me.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: (aside) Bless her! Exactly what I was at her age. (aloud) But, my dear Maud, what is to become of you?

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p:
No matter what! welcome poverty—humiliation —insult—the contempt of fools—welcome all but dependence ! I will neither dress myself at the expense of
a man I despise, control his household, owe him duty, or lead a life that is a daily lie ; neither will I marry one I love, who has dared to doubt me, to drag him into deeper poverty. (crossing to R.)
sp.stage: Enter Servant, L. 1 E.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: My Lady, there is a gentleman enquiring for Mr. Chodd.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Perhaps some electioneering friend. Shew him here. Exit Servant.
Don't leave the room, Maud, dear.

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: I was not going—why should I ?
sp.stage: Servant shews in Tom with Little Maud, L. 1 E.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: It's the tobacco man!

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: (to Child) Do I smell of smoke ? I beg your ladyship's pardon, but Mr. Chodd, the old gentleman, wished me to meet him here.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: He has just driven off to the station.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: I know I'm a few minutes behind time—there's the young lady. Good morning, Miss—Miss—I don't know the rest of her—I—I—have been detained by the— this little girl

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: (c.) A sweet little creature, Mr. Silenus.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: (L.) Stylus.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Stylus, pardon me.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: (aside) This old lady will insist on calling me Silenus ! She'd think me very rude if I called her Ariadne.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Sweet little thing! Come here, my dear! (Little Maud crosses to her) Your child, Mr.—Stylus?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: No, my lady, this is Mr. Sidney Daryl's protegee.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: (moving from Little Maud) Whose?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Sidney Daryl's (Maud advances)

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Nasty little wretch! How do you mean ? Speak, quickly!

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: I mean that Sidney pays for her education, board, and all that. Oh, he's a splendid fellow—a heart of gold! (aside) I'll put in a good word for him, as his young woman's here. I'll make her repent!

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: (r.) Come to me, child. (Little Maud crosses to her) Who are you ?

sp.speaker: L. Maud.
sp.p: I'm Mrs. Churton's little darling, and Mr. Daryl's little girl, (crosses to Tom as Maud moves away, and sinks into chair, R.)

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: (c.) His very image, (goes to Maud)

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: (L.) Bless her little tongue! I took her from the woman who takes care of her. She's going down with me to Springmead. I've bought her a new frock, all one colour, magenta, (aside) That was strong.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Did I tell you Mr. Chodd had gone ?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: I'm one too many here. I'll vamose! Good morning, my lady.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Good morning, Mr.—Bacchus.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Stylus—Stylus! I shall have to call her Ariadne. Um ! they might have asked the child to have a bit of currant cake, or a glass of currant wine. Shabby devils!
sp.stage: Exeunt Tom and Little Maud, L. 1 E.—a pause.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: (aside) Could anything have happened more delightfully?

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: (throwing herself into Lady Ptarmigant's arms) Oh, Aunty! forgive me—I was wrong—I was ungrateful —forgive me! Kiss me, and forgive me! I'll marry Mr. Chodd—anybody—do with me as you please.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: My dear niece! (affected) I—I—feel for you. I'm—I'm not so heartless as I seem. I know I'm a harsh, severe old woman, but I am a woman, and I can feel for you ! (embracing her)

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: And to think that with the same breath he could swear that he loved me, while another—this child, too ! (bursts into a flood of tears) There, aunt, I won't cry. I'll dry my eyes—I'll do your bidding You mean me well, while he—oh! (shudders) Tell Mr. Chodd I'll bear his name, and bear it worthily! (sternly—sits, R.)

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p:
(embracing—kissing her at each stop) Men are a set of brutes. I was jilted myself when I was twenty-three—and, oh, how I loved the fellow! But I asserted my dignity, and married Lord Ptarmigant, and he, and he only, can tell you how I have avenged my sex ! Cheer up, my darling ! love, sentiment, and romance are humbug!—but wealth, position, jewels, balls, presentations, a country-house, town mansion, society, power—
that's true solid happiness, and if it isn't, I don't know what is! Exeunt, R. 1 E.

div.stage: Scene Third.— The Wells at Springmead-le-Beau.—An avenue of elms, sloping off to R. u. E., on L.—house with windows, &c., on to lawn—railings at back of stage.

Garden seats, chairs, lounges, small tables, &c., discovered near house, L.—Lord Ptarmigant discovered asleep in garden-chair against house, L., his feet resting on another—Enter Chodd, Sen., down avenue, R.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Sen.
sp.p: Oh, dear! oh, dear! What a day this is! There's Johnny to be elected, and I'm expecting the first copy of the "Morning Earthquake,"—my paper! my own paper!—by the next train. Then here's Lady Ptarmigant says that positively her niece will have Johnny for her wedded husband, and in one day my Johnny is to be a husband, an M.P., and part proprietor of a daily paper ! Whew! how hot it is ! It's lucky that the wells are so near the hustings—one can run under the shade and get a cooler. Here's my lord! (waking him) My lord!

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: (waking) Oh! eh! Mr. Chodd—good morning! —how de do!

sp.speaker: Chodd, Sen.
sp.p: (sitting on stool, L.) Oh, flurried, and flustered-, and worritted. You know to-day's the election.

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: Yes, I believe there is an election going on somewhere, (calling) A tumbler of the waters No. 2.
sp.stage: Enter Waitress from house, L., places tumbler of water on table, and exit.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Sen.
sp.p: Oh, what a blessing there is no opposition! If my boy is returned (rising)
sp.stage: Enter Chodd, Jun., agitated, a placard in his hand, R. 2 E.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: Look here, guv ! look here !

sp.speaker: Chodd, Sen.
sp.p: What is it, my Johnny!

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: Don't call me Johnny ! Look here ! (shows electioneering placard, "Vote for Daryl!")

sp.speaker: Chodd, Sen.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: That vagabond has put up as candidate ! His brother used to represent the borough.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Sen.
sp.p: Then the election will be contested ?

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: Yes. (Chodd, Senior, sinks on garden chair)

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: (rising, and taking tumbler from table) Don't annoy yourself, my dear Mr. Chodd; these accidents will happen in the best regulated constituencies.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: Guv, don't be a fool!

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: Try a glass of the waters.
sp.stage: (Chodd, Sen. , takes tumbler and drinks, and the next moment ejects the water with a grimace, stamping about)

sp.speaker: Chodd, Sen.
sp.p: Oh, what filth ! O-o-o-o-o-oh!

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: It is an acquired taste, (to Waiter) Another tumbler of No. 2.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Sen.
sp.p: So, Johnny, there's to be a contest, and you won't be M.P. for Springmead after all.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: I don't know that

sp.speaker: Chodd, Sen.
sp.p: What d'ye mean?

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: Mr. Sidney Daryl may lose, and, perhaps, Mr. Sidney Daryl mayn't show. After that ball —

sp.speaker: Chodd, Sen.
sp.p: Where you lost that thousand pounds.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: Don't keep bringing that up, guvenor. After that I bought up all Mr. Daryl's bills—entered up judgment, and left them with Aaron. I've telegraphed to London, and if Aaron don't nab him in town, he'll catch him here.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Sen.
sp.p: But, Johnny, isn't that rather mean ?

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: All's fair in love and Parliament.
sp.stage: Enter Country Boy with newspaper, R. 1 E.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Mr. Chodd ?

sp.speaker: Chodd, Sen.|Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: Here!

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Just arrived.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: . "The Morning Earthquake." (they both clutch at it eagerly—each secures a paper, and sit under tree, R.)

sp.speaker: Chodd, Sen.
sp.p: (R.—reading) Look at the leader. "In the present aspect of European politics——

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: (L.) "Some minds seem singularly obtuse to the perception of an idea."

sp.speaker: Chodd, Sen.
sp.p: Johnny!

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: Guv !

sp.speaker: Chodd, Sen.
sp.p: Do you see the last leader ?

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Sen.
sp.p: (reading) "The borough of Springmead-le-Beau has for centuries been represented by the house of Daryl."

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: (reading) "A worthy scion of that ancient race intends to offer himself as candidate at the forthcoming election, and, indeed, who will dare to oppose him ?"

sp.speaker: Chodd, Sen.
sp.p: "Surely not a Mister ——"

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: "Chodd." (they rise and come down)

sp.speaker: Chodd, Sen.
sp.p: "Whoever he may be."

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: "What are the Choddian antecedents?"

sp.speaker: Chodd, Sen.
sp.p: "Whoever heard of Chodd?"

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: "To be sure a young man of that name has recently been the cause of considerable laughter at the clubs on account of his absurd attempts to become a man of fashion." (both crossing L. and R.)

sp.speaker: Chodd, Sen.
sp.p: (R.) "And to wriggle himself into Society." (crossing again)

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: (r.) Why, it's all in his favour, (in a rage)

sp.speaker: Chodd, Sen.
sp.p: In our own paper too. Oh, that villain Stylus ! (crossing R.)

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: (crossing R.) There are no more of these in the town, are there ?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Yes, sir. A man came down with two thousand ; he's giving them away everywhere.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: Confound you! (pushes him off, R. 1 E.— follows)

sp.speaker: Chodd, Sen.
sp.p: Oh, dear ! oh, dear! oh, dear! Now, my lord, isn't that too bad. (sees him asleep) He's off again! (waking him) My lord, here's the "Earthquake!" (half throwing him off seat)

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: Earthquake? Good gracious! I didn't feel anything, (rising)

sp.speaker: Chodd, Sen.
sp.p: No, no, the paper.

sp.speaker: Lord. P.
sp.p: Ah, most interesting, (drops paper, and leisurely reseats himself) My dear Mr. Chodd, I congratulate you.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Sen.
sp.p: Congratulate me ? (looks at watch) I must be off to the committee. Exit Chodd, Sen., L. 2 E.

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: Waiter! am I to have that tumbler of No. 2 ?
sp.stage: (band heard playing " Conquering Hero," and loud cheers as Lord Ptarmigant goes into house, L., and enter Sidney, O'Sullivan, Mac Usquebaugh, and Dr. Makvicz, R. U. E.—Sidney bowing off as he enters—cheers)

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: So far so good. I've seen lots of faces that I knew. I'll run this Dutch-metalled brute hard, and be in an honorable minority anyhow.
sp.stage: Enter Tom, hastily, R. 1 E.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Daryl.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Look out.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: What's the matter ?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: I met our friend Moses Aaron on the platform. He didn't see you, but what does he want here ?

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Me, if anybody, (musing) This is a shaft from the bow of Mr. John Chodd, junior. I see his aim.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: What's to be done? The voters are warm, but, despite the prestige of the family name, if you were not present —

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Besides, I couldn't be returned from Cursitor Street, M.P. for the Queen's Bench, (thinking) Did the Lamb come down with us ?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Yes—second class.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Let him stop the bailiffs—'Aaron is as timid as a girl. I'll go through here, and out by the grand entrance. Let in the Lamb, and —

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: I see.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Quick ! Exit Tom, R. 1 e.

sp.speaker: O'Sull.
sp.p: Daryl, is there any fighting to be done?

sp.speaker: Mac U.
sp.p: Or any drinking ?

sp.speaker: Dr. M.
sp.p: If so, we shall be most happy.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: No, no, thanks. Come with me—I've a treat for you.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: (laughing) The chalybeate waters.https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chalybeate Exeunt Omnes into house, L.
sp.stage: Enter Chodd, Jun., and Aaron, R. 1 E.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: You saw him go in—arrest him. The chaise is ready—take him to the next station, and all's right. I'll stay and see him captured. (Chodd in great triumph)

sp.speaker: Aaron.
sp.p: Very good, shur—do it at vunsh.
sp.stage: (is going into the house, when the Lamb springs out— Aaron staggers back—the Lamb stands in boxing attitude before the door—Tom and Six or Eight Roughs enter by avenue, R.)

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.p: (with back half turned to audience) Now, then, where are you a shovin' to ?

sp.speaker: Aaron.
sp.p: I want to passh by.

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.p: Then you can't.

sp.speaker: Aaron.
sp.p: Why not ?

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.p: (doggedly) 'Cos I'm doorkeeper, and you haven't got a check.

sp.speaker: Aaron.
sp.p: Now, Lamb, dooty'sh dooty, and—

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.p: (turning with face to audience, and bringing up the muscle of his right arm) Feel that!

sp.speaker: Aaron.
sp.p: (alarmed) Yesh, shur. (feels it slightly)

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.p: You can't come in.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: (crossing to Lamb fussily) Why not?

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.p: (looks at him, half contemptuously, half comically) 'Cos that sez I musn't let you. Feel it ! (taps muscle)

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: Thank you, some other time, (crossing, R.)
sp.stage: (The Roughs surround him, jeer, and prepare to hustle him—Tom mounts seat, R.)

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Vote for Daryl!

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.p: (making up to Aaron in sparring attitude, who retreats in terror) Are yer movin' ?

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: Do your duty. (Roughs laugh)

sp.speaker: Aaron.
sp.p: I can't—they are many, I am few.
sp.stage: (cheers without, R.)

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: (losing his presence of mind) Particular business requires me at the hustings.
sp.stage: (goes off R., midst jeers and laughter of Roughs)

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.p: (at same time advancing upon Aaron) Are yer movin'.

sp.speaker: Aaron.
sp.p: Yesh, Mr. Lamb, (by this time he has backed close to Tom, perched upon the seat, who bonnets him)

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Vote for Daryl!
sp.stage: (Aaron is hustled off R. 1 E., by Mob, followed leisurely by Lamb)

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: (on chair) Remember, gentlemen, the officers of the law—the officers of the sheriff—are only in the execution of their duty, (shouts and uproar without) Don't offer any violence, (shouts) Don't tear them limb from limb ! (shouts, followed by a loud shriek—Tom leaps from chair, dances down stage, and exit, R. U. E.)
sp.stage: Enter Lady Ptarmigant and Chodd, Sen., R. 2 E.— Lady Ptarmigant is dressed in mauve—Chodd escorts her to house, L.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Sen.
sp.p: But if he is absent from his post ?

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: His post must get on without him. Really, my dear Mr. Chodd, you must allow me to direct absolutely. If you wish your son to marry Miss Hetherington, now is the time—now or never.
sp.stage: Exit into house, L.—Chodd exits, R. 1 E.
Enter Chodd, Jun. and Maud, dressed in mauve, R. U. E.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p:
Miss Hetherington, allow me to offer you a seat, (she sits under tree, R.—aside) Devilish awkward! Lady Ptarmigant says "Strike while the iron's hot;" but I want to be at the hustings. I've made my speech to the electors, and now I must do my courting. She looks awfully proud. I wish I could pay some fellow to do this for me. Miss Hetherington, a—a—a— I got the speech I spoke just now off by heart. I wish I'd got this written for me too. Miss Hetherington, I—I am emboldened by the—by what I have just been told by our esteemed correspondent, Lady Ptar—I mean by your amiable aunt. I—I— (boldly) I have a large
fortune, and my prospects are bright and brilliant— bright and brilliant. I—I am of a respectable family, which has always paid its way. I have entered on a political career, which always pays its way; and I mean some day to make my name famous. My lady has doubtless prepared you for the hon—I offer you my— my humble hand, and large—I may say colossal fortune.

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: (L.) Mr. Chodd, I will be plain with you.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: (R.) Impossible for Miss Hetherington to be plain.

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: You offer me your hand: I will accept it.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: Oh, joy ! Oh — (endeavouring to take her hand)

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: Please hear me out. On these conditions.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: Pin money no object. Settle as much on you as you like.

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: I will be your true and faithful wife—I will bear your name worthily; but you must understand our union is a union of convenience.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: Convenience!

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: Yes ; that love has no part in it.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: Miss Hetherington—may I say Maud— I love you—I adore you with my whole heart and fortune, (aside) I wonder how they're getting on at the hustings.

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: I was saying, Mr. Chodd

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: Call me John—your own John! (seizing her hand—she shudders, and withdraws it)

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: (struggling with herself) I was saying that the affection which a wife should bring the man she has elected as ——(cheers without)

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: (speaking without) Electors of Springmead.

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: We hardly know sufficient of each other to warrant ——

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: (without) I need not tell you who I am. (cheers —Maud trembles)

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: We are almost strangers.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Nor what principles I have been reared in.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: The name of Chodd, if humble, is at least wealthy.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: I am a Daryl; and my politics those of the Daryls. (cheers)

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: (aside) This is awkward, (to Maud) As to our being strangers —

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: I am no stranger, (cheers) I have grown up to be a man among you. There are faces I see in the crowd I am addressing, men of my own age, whom I remember children, (cheers) There are faces among you who remember me when I was a boy. (cheers) In the political union between my family and Springmead, there is more than respect and sympathy, there is sentiment. (cheers)

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: Confound the fellow! Dearest Miss Hetherington—Dearest Maud—you have deigned to say you will be mine.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Why, if we continue to deserve your trust, plight your political faith to another?

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: (overcome) Mr. Chodd, I —

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: My own bright, particular Maud !

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Who is my opponent?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: (without, R.) Nobody. (a loud laugh)

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: What is he ?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Not much, (a roar of laughter)

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: I have no doubt he is honest and trustworthy, but why turn away an old servant to hire one you don't know? (cheers) Why turn off an old love that you have tried and proved for a new one? (cheers) I don't know what the gentleman's politics may be. (laugh) Or those of his family, (roar of laughter) I've tried to find out, but I can't. To paraphrase the ballad :—
sp.l: I've searched through Hansard, journals,
Books, De Brett, and Burke, and Dodd,
And my head—my head is aching, To find out the name of Chodd.
sp.stage: (loud laughter and three cheers—Maud near fainting)

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: I can't stand this; I must be off to the hustings, Miss Heth! Oh! she's fainting. What shall I do ? Lady Ptarmigant! Oh, here she comes! Waiter, a tumbler of number 2. Runs off, R. 2 e.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: (without) And I confidently await the result which will place me at the head of the poll. (cheers)
sp.stage: Enter Lord and Lady Ptarmigant, from house, L.—Lady Ptarmigant attends to Maud.

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: 'Twas nothing—a slight faintness—an attack of —

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: An attack of Chodd, I think ! What a dreadful person my lady is, to be sure, (aside—sits, L.)

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: (to Maud) Have you done it?

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: And you are to be his wife ?

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: Yes. (cheers)
sp.stage: Enter Sidney, O'Sullivan, Mac Usquebaugh and Doctor Makvicz, R. 2 e.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: (coming down, L.) Tom, I feel so excited—so delighted—so happy—so—(sees Maud, stops, takes his hat off—Maud bows coldly)— In my adversary's colours!

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: (r.) That fellow, Sidney!

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: (c.—aside) It seems hard to see him there, and not to speak to him for the last time.
sp.stage: (is about to advance when Tom brings on Little Maud, R. u. e., dressed in magenta—Maud recedes —Lord Ptarmigant goes to sleep in garden seat, L.)

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: The tobacco man !

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: (down, L.) Ariadne! (Sidney kisses Little Maud)
sp.stage: Enter Chodd, Jun., R. U. E., and down, R.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: (with a withering glance at Sidney) Maud, my child, here's Mr. Chodd.
sp.stage: (Chodd, Jun. , crossing R. c, gives his arm to Maud— Sidney stands with Little Maud, L. C. —All go off, R. u. E., except Lady Ptarmigant, Sidney, Tom and Lord Ptarmigant)

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: (L.) On his arm! Well, I deserve it ! I am poor!

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: (r.) Mr. Daryl. (Sidney bows)

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: (L.) Ariadne is about to express her feelings; I shall go! Exit, R. u. E.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Lady Ptarmigant!

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p:
I cannot but express my opinion of your
conduct. For a long time I have known you to be the associate of prize fighters, betting men, race horses, authors, and other such low persons; but despite that, I thought you had some claims to be a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: In what way have I forfeited Lady Ptarmigant's good opinion?

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: In what, sir? In daring to bring me, your kinswoman, and a lady—in daring to bring into the presence of the foolish girl you professed to love—that child—your illegitimate offspring !
sp.stage: (Lord Ptarmigant awakes)

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: (stung) Lady Ptarmigant, do you know who that child is?

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Perfectly! (with a sneer)

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: I think not. She is the lawful daughter of your dead, and only son, Charles!

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Two days before he sailed for the Crimea, he called at my chambers, and told me that he felt convinced he should never return. He told me too of his connection with a poor and humble girl, who would shortly become the mother of his child. I saw from his face that the bullet was cast that would destroy him, and I begged him to legitimatize one, who, though of his blood, might not bear his name. Like a brave fellow, a true gentleman, on the next day he married.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: How disgraceful!

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Joined his regiment, and, as you know, fell at Balaclava.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: My poor—poor boy.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: His death broke his wife's heart—she too died.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: What a comfort!

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: I placed the child with a good motherly woman, and I had intended, for the sake of my old friend, Charley, to educate her, and to bring her to you, and say, take her, she is your lawful grandchild, and a lady pur sang ; love her and be proud of her, for the sake of the gallant son, who galloped to death in the service of his country.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: (affected) Sidney!

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p:
I did not intend that you should know this for some time. I had some romantic notion of making it a
reason for your consent to my marriage with—(Lady Ptarmigant takes Little Maud) with Miss Hetherington —that is all over now. The ill opinion, with which you have lately pursued me, has forced this avowal from me.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: (to child) My darling! Ah! my poor Charley's very image! My poor boy! my poor boy!

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: (who has been listening, advancing, L. ) Sidney, let my son Charley's father thank you. You have acted like a kinsman and a Daryl! (affected)

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Sidney, forgive me !

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: (c.) Pray forget it, Lady Ptarm —

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: I will take care that Miss Hetherington shall know

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: (hotly) What! did she too suspect! Lady Ptarmigant, it is my request—nay, if I have done anything to deserve your good opinion, my injunction—that Miss Hetherington is not informed of what has just passed. If she has thought that I could love another— she is free to her opinion! (goes up, and comes down, R., with the child)

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: But I shall tell her.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: (astonished) You! (aside) Don't you think, under the circumstances, it would be better—

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: I shall act as I think best.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Ferdinand ! (authoritatively)

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: Lady Ptarmigant, it is not often I speak, goodness knows! but on a question that concerns my honour, and yours, I shall not be silent.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: (c.) Ferdinand! (imploringly)

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: Lady Ptarmigant, I am awake, and you will please to follow my instructions, (crossing, c.) What is my grand-daughter's name ?

sp.speaker: L. Maud.
sp.p: Maud.

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: Maud, Maud—is it Maud! (playfully)
sp.stage: (Lord Ptarmigant lifts her in his arms, and is carrying her off)

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: My lord! consider—people are looking !

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: Let 'em look—they'll know I'm a grandfather !
sp.stage: Exit Lord Ptarmigant, with Little Maud and Lady Ptarmigant, R. u. e. avenue.
Tom runs on, R. u. e.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: (L.) It's all right, Sid. Three of Chodd's Committee have come over to us. They said that so long as a Daryl was not put up, they felt at liberty to support him, but now—(seeing that Sidney is affected) What's the matter ?

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: (r.) Nothing.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Ah, that means love! I hope to be able to persuade the majority of Chodd's Committee to resign ; and, if they resign, he must too, and we shall walk over the course. (Sidney goes up and sits, L.—aside) Cupid's carriage stops the way again. Confound that nasty, naughty, naked little boy! I wonder if he'd do less mischief if they put him into knickerbockers. Exit, R. 1 e.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Mr. Chodd shall not have Springmead.
sp.stage: Enter Maud, leading Little Maud by the hand, R. U. E.— Sidney's face is buried in his hands on the table.

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: (kissing the child, then advancing slowly to Sidney) Sidney!

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: (rising) Maud—Miss Hetherington !

sp.speaker: L. Maud.
sp.p: Uncle, this is my new aunt. She's my aunt and you're my uncle. You don't seem pleased to see each other though—ain't you? Aunt, why don't you kiss uncle ?

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: (r., after a pause) Sidney, I have to beg your forgiveness for the—the—mistake which—

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: (L.) Pray don't mention it, Maud—Miss Hetherington. It is not of the —

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: (R.) It is so hard to think ill of those we have known. (Child goes up, R.)

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: I think that it must be very easy! Let me take this opportunity of apologizing personally, as I have already done by letter, for my misconduct at the ball. I had heard that you were about to—to—

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: Marry! Then you were in error. Since then I have accepted Mr. Chodd. (pause)

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: I congratulate you. (turns his face aside)

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: You believed me to be false—believed it without enquiry !

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: As you believed of me!

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: Our mutual poverty prevented.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: (bursting out) Oh, yes, we are poor ! We are poor! We loved each other—but we were poor! We loved each other—but we couldn't take a house in a square! We loved each other—but we couldn't keep a carriage ! We loved each other—but we had neither gold, purple, plate, or mansion in the country ! You were right to leave me, and to marry a gentleman—rich in all these assurances of happiness!

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: Sidney, you are cruel.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: I loved you, Maud; loved you with my whole heart and soul since we played together as children, and you grew till I saw you a lovely blushing girl, and now— pshaw ! this is folly, sentiment, raving madness ! Let me wish you joy—let me hope you will be happy.

sp.speaker: L. Maud.
sp.p: (coming down, c.) Uncle, you mustn't make my new aunt cry. Go and make it up with her, and kiss her.
sp.stage: Lady Ptarmigant, Lord Ptarmigant, and Lord Cloudwrays have entered during the last speech, R. U. E.

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: Farewell, Sidney! (holding out her hand)

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Farewell!

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: (advancing, c.) Farewell! What nonsense : two young people so fond of each other. Sidney— Maud, dear, you have my consent.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: (L. C, astonished) Lady Ptarmigant!

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: (r. c.) I always liked you, Sidney, though, I confess, I didn't always shew it.

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: (L.) I can explain my lady's sudden conversion—at least, Cloudwrays can.

sp.speaker: Lord C.
sp.p: (r.) Well, Sid, I'm sorry to be the bearer of good news—I mean of ill news; but your brother— poor Percy—he—a

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: Dead!

sp.speaker: Lord C.
sp.p: The news came by the mail to the Club, so as I'd nothing to do, I thought I'd come down to congratulate —I mean condole with you.

sp.speaker: Lord P.
sp.p: Bear up, Sidney, your brother's health was bad before he left us.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: First the son, and then the father.

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: (L. C.) Sidney !

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: (catching her hand) Maud!

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: No, no—not now—you are rich, and I am promised.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Why, you wicked girl; you wouldn't marry a man you didn't love, would you? Where are your principles? (Lord Ptarmigant sits on garden seat, L., with Little Maud)

sp.speaker: Maud.
sp.p: But—but—Mr. Chodd?

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: What on earth consequence is Mr. Chodd ?
sp.stage: Enter Chodd, Sen. and Chodd, Jun., avenue, R.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Sen.
sp.p: My lady, it's all right, Johnny has been accepted!
sp.stage: (Maud goes up and sits, L. C. —Sidney and Lord Cloudwrays also go up with her)

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: (L.) By whom ?

sp.speaker: Chodd, Sen.
sp.p: (r.) By Miss Hetherington—by Maud!

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Why, you must be dreaming, the election has turned your brain—my niece marry a Chodd !

sp.speaker: Chodd, Sen.|Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: My lady!

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Nothing of the sort; I was only joking, and thought you were, too. (aside) The impertinence of the lower classes in trying to ally themselves with us! (going up, L.)

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: Guv.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Sen.
sp.p: Johnny!

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: We're done! (crosses, L.)
sp.stage: Loud cheering. Enter Tom, E. U. E., who whispers and congratulates Sidney. Enter a Gentleman, R. 1 E., who whispers to Chodd, Sen. condolingly and exit, R. 1. E. Chodd, Sen. (R., shouting) Johnny !

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: (L.) Guv.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Sen.
sp.p: They say there's no hope, and advise us to withdraw from the contest.
sp.stage: (All congratulate Sidney, up stage)

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Sir Sidney Daryl, M.P., looks like old times. (to Lord Ptarmigant) My lord, congratulate him.

sp.speaker: Lord. P.
sp.p: (waking and shaking Chodd, Jun. by the hand) Receive my congratulations.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: Oh ! it's the wrong man !

sp.speaker: Chodd, Sen.
sp.p: (R.) Mr. Stylus, I may thank you for this.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: (r. c.) And yourself, you may. I brought out your journal, engaged your staff, and you tried to throw me over. You've got your reward. Morning paper! (throws papers in the air)
sp.stage: Enter Aaron with hat broken and head bound up, R. U. E.

sp.speaker: Aaron.
sp.p: (c, to Sidney) Arresht you at the shoot of (Chodds rub their hands in triumph)

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: (r. c.) Too late ! too late! He's a member of Parliament.
sp.stage: (Chodd jun.and Sen. turn into R. and L. corners)

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: (L. c, to Tom) I haven't taken the seat or the oaths yet.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: (r. c.) They don't know that.

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: We can settle it another way. (taking out pocket book and looking at Chodd, Jun.) Some time ago I was fortunate enough to win a large sum of money, this way if you please, (goes up with Aaron, and gives money, notes, &c.)

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: Pays his own bills, which I'd bought up, with my money.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Sen.
sp.p: (crossing, L.) Then, Johnny, you won't get into society.

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: (coming down, R.) Never mind, Mr. Chodd, your son shall marry a lady.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Sen.|Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: Eh!

sp.speaker: Lady P.
sp.p: I promise to introduce you to one of blue blood.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Sen.
sp.p: Blue blood.

sp.speaker: Chodd, Jun.
sp.p: Blue bl—— I'd rather have it the natural colour.
sp.stage: Cheers—Enter O'Sullivan and Committee, R. U. E. Stage full. Church bells heard.

sp.speaker: O'Sull.
sp.p:
(r.) Sir Sidney Daryl we have heard the news. In our turn we have to inform you that your
adversaries have retired from the contest, and you are member for Springmead. (cheers) We, your committee, come to weep with you for the loss of a brother, to joy with you on your accession to a title and your hereditary honours. Your committee most respectfully beg to be introduced to Lady Daryl. (with intention and Irish gallantry)
sp.stage: (Sidney shews Maud the magenta ribbon—she places her hand in his)

sp.speaker: Sidney.
sp.p: (c.) Gentlemen, I thank you ; I cannot introduce you to Lady Daryl, for Lady Daryl does not yet exist. In the meantime I have permission to present you to Miss Hetherington.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: (leaping on chair, R., and waving handkerchief) Three cheers for my lady !

div.p: (All cheer—church bells—band plays "Conquering Hero." Girl at window of house waves handkerchief and Child a stick with magenta streamer attached. Countrymen, &c. wave hats—band plays, &c.
div.stage: Roughs. Countryfolks. Girl and Child Sidney and Maud. Makvicz, Tom. Lord P., L. Maud. Mac Usqbaugh. Lady P., Lord C. O'Sullivan. Chodd, Sen., Chodd, Jun.
Curtain.
